couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/3.-eft.html.title: 3. EFT
couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/3.-eft.html.description:
Collaborative alliance: models and provides a secure base. Emotion is primary in organizing attachment behaviora and the ways self and other are experienced in intimate relationships (primary and secondary emotions)
Attachments are adaptive and healthy
Problems are maintained by interaction patterns and by the dominant organization of emotional experience of each partner. Change occurs through new emotional experience in the context of attachment-salient interactions as they occur in session. (make it important to attachment, example: new parents, partners are not used to the difference in attachment and time spent in the relationship)
The 'client' is the relationship. Gas lighting is an attachment injury Creation of new cycles of secure bonding, which offer an antidote to negative cycles and positively redefine the nature of the relationship. Create a safe, collaborative alliance. Access, reformulate, and expand the emotional responses that guide the couple's interaction. Restructure those interactions in the direction of the accessibility and responsiveness that builds, secure lasting bonds. Step 1: Identify the relational conflict issues. Step 2: Identify the negative interaction cycle
Step 3: Access the unacknowledged attachment oriented emotions underlying the interaction cycle. Step 4: Reframe the problem in terms of the cycle, underlying emotions that accompany it, and attachment vulnerabilities and needs. Step 5: Promote identification with disowned attachment needs and aspects of self. Step 6: Promote each partner's acceptance of the other's experience. Step 7: Facilitate the expression of needs and wants to restructure the interactional based on new understandings and to create bonding events. Step 8: Facilitate the emergence of new solutions to old problems. Step 9: Consolidate new positions and cycles of attachment behavior. Alliance
Commenting on the process, and interpreting with attachment language to draw out each partner's emotional experience. Enactments with expanded emotional experiences. Commenting on the experiences so that they can be integrated. How can we help you process when you get loud?

couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/4.-gottman..title: 4. Gottman
couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/4.-gottman..description: Most relationship conflict is not solvable, but perpetual based on personality characteristics of the partners. This can lead to grid lock. Gridlock conflict is about the escalation of negative affect reciprocity To get 'dialogue' with a perpetual issue, you have to understand the existential nature of it or the 'dreams within conflict' Building positivity during non-conflict and conflict is essential for lasting change. Friendship processes control the effectiveness and thresholds of the repair of problematic interaction. Couple's construction of a 'shared meaning system' facilitates stability and happiness. Three systems need to be understood (conflict, friendship/intimacy/positive affect, and shared meaning) need to be understood to intervene. For Gottman, theory must provide a 'recipe' for therapeutic change Repair: Processing fights and regrettable incidents. Reduce the use of the 4 Horsemen. Gottman-Rapport Blueprint for Practice Exercise (Speaker Listener Activity) (postpone persuasion, until both partners acknowledge the others perspective and emotion to the other's satisfaction) Problem-solving, persuasion, and compromise Blueprint for perpetual unsolvable conflict (Dreams within conflict, one person takes a turn while the other person is listen, not trying to persuade, the objective is to reflect back what you hear) Down-regulating negative affect with physiological soothing (biofeedback) Get couples to notice positives and accept influence. They are going to acknowledge their partner. Help couples turn toward each other when bids for connection are made. Build positive affect separately from helping to decrease ineffective conflict. 'Savor' positive affect 5 to 1 ratio vs. 0.8 to 1 Emotional connection during everyday moments (build love maps, build a culture of appreciation, turn towards bids for connection, engage in emotion coaching, increase and savor positive affect) Daily stress-reducing conversation Build affection, good sex, romance, and passion Process failed bods for emotional connection Here they move to more emotion focused techniques, and theory, using a metaphor of attachment + Use card decks to help couple members identify emotions, talk about their beliefs about emotion etc. Encourage emotion coaching Create shared meaning by making rituals of emotional connection intentional. Create shared meanings by making goals and values intentional.

couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/6.-discernm.title: 6. Discernment Counseling and Divorce
couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/6.-discernm.description:
Read @dohertyHelpingCouplesBrink2017
Read Research Citations/A/@abbasiPolarizedCouplesTherapy2017
Read @allanUseEmotionallyFocused2016
Read @dohertyDiscernmentCounselingMixed2016
Read Chapter 21 of @lebowClinicalHandbookCouple2023 Emotional process Pull couple back to the goals. Build alliance Educate people on how parents can maintain a relationship with their children and not to pull the children between the parents. What is in the way of making a clear back Establish clear and 'good enough' communication How do you establish rules of communication? How do you negotiate when they are broken? They need to learn to disengage from each other. Couples that do not live together can stop talking to each other. They need to come up with enough communication that it is enough. The more they are fighting the more they are Reattribution Creating a new script Helping the couple figure out th
Goals for Discernment Counseling: Clarity and confidence about a direction for the marriage based on a deeper understanding of what has happened to the marriage, and each person's contributions to the problems. Discernment counseling ends with a decision to take one of three paths: Couple therapy Divorce Status Quo Could be up to 30% of couples who come to therapy, but our models and techniques do not prepare us for these types of couples (one is leaning in the other leaning out). These types of couples are difficult to treat because of their conflicting goals for therapy. One to say it is worth investing in the relationship and we can fix the problems, the other perhaps to prove that we have done all we can it is time to split. Doherty believed that before trying to do any sort of couple work, these couples needed to decide if that is what they wanted. Short term processes: 1-5 sessions Goal is to get a deeper understanding of what has happened in the relationship and each partner's contributions to the problems. Three paths: Status quo Divorce Therapy Couple together One spouse separately Summary to the other spouse One spouse separately Summary to the other spouse Couple together
Not much research on Mixed-Agenda Couples couples and how to work with them. Most work suggests that Mixed-Agenda Couples couples are common (about 30%). Outcome research is sparse but suggest that these couples when treated with couple therapy are more likely to separate. Also evidence that people going through the divorce process believe the marriage could be saved (about 26%) and are interested in reconciliation services (about 33%). Lots of evidence of ambivalence about the divorce and the relationship. About 66.2% of folks in the divorce process were sure they wanted the divorce, 16.5% had mixed feelings, and 9.8% would consider reconciliation. Conclusion: We need some way of providing services to folks considering divorce to help them with their mixed feelings and decide on a path. 100 cases evaluated 97 heterosexual couples, 3 same-sex Married an average of 15.5 years Highly distressed based on the DAS short form 51% had consulted a divorce attorney Well educated 48% came based on self-referral, 34% from therapists or social service agencies, 11% from attorneys or judges. Findings: Average number of sessions 3.61 47% decided on path 3 (therapy), 41% separation/divorce, and 12% status quo. Contact with a divorce attorney associated with a lower likelihood of path 3, and higher likelihood of path 2. At follow-up, those who chose path 2: 90% were divorced or in the process, one couple reconciled, and 3 were on hold. Those who chose path 3: 36% reconciled, 6% in process, 28% had divorced, 17% were in process of divorce, and 13% were on hold. Ask what they understand about discernment counseling. For the leaning-out partner: Make sure they feel heard and that they understand the process of discernment and that it is different than couple therapy then ask if they are still seeking some sort of clarity on the process of divorce, and how confident they are in their decision. For the leaning-in partner: They recommend they read 'The Divorce Remedy by Michele Weiner-Davis', which provides advice for folks who have just found out their partner wants a divorce. Recommended that you contact both partners separately for these intake conversations. Block out 2 hours for the first session. Meet together to ask questions, meet with each partner separately, provide summaries to the partners after each individual session, then come back together to summarize the set of sessions, therapist's impressions of the couple, then if both partners agree, schedule the second session. Questions for both: What happened to your marriage that's gotten you to the point where divorce is a possibility? Can you tell me what you have done to try to fix the problems in the marriage, whether on your own or with help? What role, if any, do your children play in your decision making about the future of your relationship? Can you tell me about a time in your relationship, since the time you met, when you felt the most connection and joy? Questions for Leaning-Out partner (see this person first): Tell me more about your pain and reasons for considering divorce. (Within no more than 10 minutes) switch to a conversation about the paths. Find out how far they have gone in formalizing divorce plans (contacted attorney, papers drawn up, etc.) Ask them their perspective on their contributions to the problems in the marriage. Prepare a summary statement for the other partner about something they have taken away from the individual time, then invite partner 2 in the room to hear the summary statement. Now work with the leaning-in partner: Help them articulate that they understand their partner's concerns and can understand why their partner might be interested in divorce. Ask about their perspective on their own contributions to the problems in the relationship. Help them figure out how to respond without being too anxious or withdrawing completely. Summary statement: Must convey the sense that the leaning-in partner understands why their partner is contemplating divorce, and some empathy for this position. Once both people are in the room again, and the leaning-in partner has shared their summary statement, then the therapist shares their observations. What themes have you noticed, and your perception of how they got to this place. Couple does not have to agree on a path at the end of this session, but they may, they recommend that the couple return for at least a 2 nd discernment session before deciding, especially Path 3. Goals: Clarity Confidence More understanding 90-minute sessions: Time together Time separately with summaries Time together wrap-up Check-in: 3 goals: Learning where each partner is in their discernment process Reminding partners of the goals of discernment Acoiding an open-ended invitation to talk about the relationship problems. Leaning-out partner: Move to help them see their contributions Leaning-In partner: Move to help them develop a plan for change Discernment is not the same for both partners, leaning in partner carries a bigger burden of leadership about what they may need to change in order for the marriage to be more viable. Summaries should become more self-revealing and intense, therapist feedback can also be more in-depth in terms of positives and negatives. Need to prepare partners for the work that will need to be done in therapy. If you are going to be the couple therapist have a transition session possibly using the Agreement to Pursue Reconciliation Form (pg. 103). Generate personal agendas for change (pg. 105) and have them share with each other. Explore the divorce decision: Freedom Relief Painful letting go Deal with the emotional fall-out of the decision Prepare couple for a constructive divorce process in their interactions with each other, in their dealings with their children, and in choosing professional assistance. Offer more sessions about a constructive divorce process. Monitor the emotions and although emphasizing with each partner interrupt intense emotional outpourings from leaning-in partner, keep things as calm as possible. In your summary, state any commonalities you have heard about their divorce hopes and dreams for their children, co-parenting, and their interest in mediation and collaborative divorce processes. Why couples may choose this path: Leaning-out partner still can't decide and leaning-in partner is still leaning-in. The couple may have gotten enough from the session (relief, able to talk more calmly about the issues, feel heard for the first time, etc.) so they feel ready to continue the relationship without more therapy. It may also be it doesn't seem like the right time for a big change in their lives (considering their children or other situations). Some believe that situations that are impinging on their relationship might change so they decide to wait it out.

couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/7.-sexual-d.title: 7. Sexual Disorders and Therapy
couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/7.-sexual-d.description:
Read Weeks et al., (2020) (Chapters 2-5) “The Sexual Response Cycle.png” could not be found. Masters & Johnson's EPOR Model: Excitement The first phase in the EPOR model, in which the first physical changes of sexual arousal occur. Vasocongestion The swelling of erectile tissues due to increased blood flow during sexual arousal. Male: “Male EPOC Cycle.png” could not be found. Female: “Female Arousal State.png” could not be found.
Sex Flush: A darkening or reddening of the skin of the chest area that occurs in some people during sexual arousal. Plateau:
The second phase in the EPOR model during which sexual arousal levels off (reaches a plateau) and remains at an elevated level of excitement.
Tenting A widening of the inner two-thirds of the vaginal during sexual arousal. Orgasm Resolution A heterogeneous group of disorders that are characterized by: A clinically significant disturbance in a person's ability to respond sexually or experience sexual pleasure Three female sexual disorders:
Female Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder
Female Orgasmic Disorder
Genito-Pelvic Pain/Penetration Disorder (GPPPD) Four Male Sexual Disorders:
Male Hypoactive Sexual Desire Disorder
Erectile Disorder
Delayed Ejaculation
Premature Ejaculation Other categories:
Substance/Medication-Induced Sexual Dysfunction
Other Specified Sexual Dysfunction (includes distressing sexual symptoms but does not meet the criteria for a specific disorder with reasons why)
Unspecified Sexual Dysfunction (same as above with no reasons why) Specifiers Lifelong vs. Acquired Generalized vs. Situational Severity of Distress Individual/Biological Individual/Psychological The Dyadic Relationship Family of Origin Influences Contextual Factors (Society/Culture/History/Religion etc.)
Female Sexual Interest (Arousal Disorder): Absent/reduced interest in sexual activity Absent/reduced sexual/erotic thoughts or fantasies No/reduced initiation of sexual activity Typically unreceptive to a partner's attempt to initiate Absent/reduced sexual excitement/pleasure during sexual activity in all or almost all (75%-100%) sexual encounters Absent/reduced sexual interest/arousal in response to any internal or external sexual/erotic cues Absent/reduced genital or non-genital sensations during sexual activity in all or almost all (75%-100%) sexual encounters The changes to this definition (from previous DSM version) was in recognition that sexual desire is less spontaneous for women than men, and more related to contextual and relational variables. Authors believed that this helped to depathologize women for the lack of so-called spontaneous desire, especially because these symptoms need to be present for at least 6 months to render this diagnosis.
Female Orgasmic Disorder: Marked delay in, marked infrequency of or absence of orgasm or markedly reduced intensity or orgasmic sensations (essential to assess for levels of distress around this).
Genito-Pelvic Pain (Penetration Disorder) (GPPPD): Vaginal penetration during intercourse Marked vulvovaginal or pelvic pain during vaginal intercourse or penetration attempts marked fear or anxiety about vulvovaginal or pelvic pain in anticipation of, during, or as a result of vaginal penetration. Marked tensing or tightening of the pelvic floor muscles during attempted vaginal penetration. Important to explore all the factors that may be at play here (physiological, cognitive, emotional, behavioral and interpersonal, including past trauma).
Male Hypoactive Sexual Desire Disorder: Male must present with persistently or recurrent deficient (or absent) sexual/erotic thoughts or fantasies and desire for sexual activity. Not much known about this, and it rarely the primary presenting concern.
Erectile Disorder (at least one of 3) Marked difficulty in obtaining an erection during sexual activity. Marked difficulty in maintainig an erection until completion of sexual activity. Marked decrease in erectil rigidity. Prevalence increases with age and other disease states. Medical screenings are essential when working with clients with this condition.
Premature Ejaculation A persistent or recurrent pattern of ejaculation occurring during partnered sexual activity within approximately 1-minute following vaginal penetration and before the individual wishes it. Symptoms of erectile disfunction and premature ejaculation are often co-occurring. Performance anxiety is often found with either disorder.
Delayed Ejaculation: Marked delay in ejaculation or marked infrequency or absence of ejaculation and the individual must desire ejaculation. It is probably more common to see couples who do not have diagnosable disorders but have complaints about the sexual aspects of their relationships. The most common problem is desire discrepancy. Some conditions are currently being considered for inclusion in the DSM: Sexual Compulsivity, Addition, or Hypersexuality Gender Non-Conformity (DSM-5 less restrictive, some things that would automatically mean a disorder are now only a disorder if there is distress or impairment around the activity) Persistent Genital Arousal Disorder (for females, unrelenting genital arousal that does not diminish with orgasm) Sexual Aversion Disorder (no longer listed as a sexual disorder, but as a phobia) Male Dyspareunia (men who had persistent pain with sexual activity; could be as simple as an infection, or more complex floor abnormalities). More comprehensive than talking about symptoms alone. Include the following: The couple's perception of the problem (s) Current baseline of individual and relational functioning Physical status of each partner The couple's expectations or goals for the treatment Realistic treatment goals Level of sexual desire of each partner Perceived degree of sexual satisfaction Level of distress experienced because of the sexual problem Impact on the intimate relationship The functions of sex in the relationship Get a sexual history from each partner (can be questionnaires or through interviewing, authors suggest conjoint interviewing to develop alliance and watch the process, they recommend flexible use of conjoint and individual sessions). Authors recommend that therapists understand their own sexual so that they can avoid inadvertently or overtly shaming. Use more open-ended questions and be careful about the words you use (i.e., have you been unfaithful? Vs. Do you have intimate relations with others in addition to your primary partner?) Adopt a stance of both never assuming and always assuming: Never assume a client's sexual orientation Always assume that everyone does everything Never assume that clients are educated about all aspects of sexuality Book provides lots of suggestions for how to ask questions to get at specific diagnoses and questions to ask when taking a sexual history. Focus on gender, romantic love, attachment, intimacy, communication, gender orientation, and other themes associated with sexuality (provides questions to ask to complete the genogram) Beliefs about being a man or a woman Family patterns of relationships Couple relationship patterns (affairs, divorces, abandonment, loyalty and sacrifice) Family impact on current gender behavior Peer expectations Cultural expectations Assessment in sex therapy is essential for determining a treatment plan (like all therapy)
There are formal assessment instruments but they were mostly designed for previous DSM versions, not the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) -5, they can still be used but may not be as useful for diagnosis. Behavioral assessment (i.e., similar to BCT) Physiological measures (scores for respondent's perceptions of satisfaction with, or pain during phases of the sexual response cycle). Relationship issues vs. Sexual disorders (need to determine which is a priority for the couple) Thorough Assessment Collaborate on treatment planning Is the couple ready? When to start sex therapy and its techniques

couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/8.-systemic.title: 8. Systemic Sex Therapy
couples-(hdfs-8876)/lectures/8.-systemic.description:
Weeks et al., (Chapters 1, 6-13, and 16) These techniques are not for the usual clients with sexual discrepancies (i.e., one client has a higher libido than the other). It is for individuals that struggle with sexual disorders/dysfunctions. Therapist directed or structured. You can collaborate, but the therapist is not coming up with their own examples. Related to practicing activities learned in sessions and other behaviors that are carefully crafted and explained during the session. Expected to facilitate a therapeutic effect. Need to be practical. Practiced in small increments toward a goal (typically not erection, penetration, or orgasm). Major goal is to reduce anxiety and reinforce new behavior. Need to be relevant to the issues, and within the ability of the client or couple. Make the assignment (perhaps in writing as well) and then work with the couple and what they think about the assignment, ay questions they have and any fears ,, they have about starting the assignment. Collaborate so that the clients are invested and the assignment is tailored to them. Negotiate the schedule, who initiates, and make sure they clearly understand what they are supposed to do. Process the assignment the next session, what worked, what didn't, etc. Access effort. Most effective evidence-based practices in combination with psychotherapy. For sex therapy, it includes information about sexual functioning, sexual disorders, sexual orientation, gender diversity, STI’s. Comes in many forms (helps dispel myths, normalize, and inform) Bibliotherapy (books, internet-based material, TV shows, or other forms of media) Ensure to read, listen, and watch to the examples you will be giving to clients. Need to gauge the clients' tastes and tolerance in using these resources. Incorporates psychoeducation about the sexual response and a series of incremental physical exercises performed outside of the therapeutic setting. Viewed as a form of desensitization intended to promote relaxation, communication and attention to physical sensations of touch, and the physical emotional connections between partners. Combined with mindfulness (being present in the moment, not thinking about past or future; making no judgements, not spectating). Authors use a more systemic approach to sensate focus then originally designed. They include both partners, and create smaller increments of behaviors moving toward genital touch then Masters and Johnson. 9 functions of sensate focus: Become more aware of sensations Focus solely on one's own needs for pleasure Communicate sensual and sexual needs, wishes and desires Increase awareness of partner's sensual and sexual needs Expand the repertoire of intimate touch, sensual and sexual behaviors Learn to appreciate foreplay or touch as an end in itself rather than a means to an end Create positive relationship experiences Build sexual desire Enhance the level of love, caring, commitment, intimacy cooperation, and sexual interest in the relationship Describe what is involved, noting each partner's reaction (see questions on page 183) What is 'good enough' sex? Go slowly if one or both partners express hesitation or ambivalence or simple refusal. Tailored to the specific needs of the couple. The 'goal' of the exercise is the touch and the experience of the sensations, not erection, orgasm, penetration, etc. Specific assignments should occur weekly, so assignments can be reviewed and revised. Remind couples that this is a chance to rebuild physical and emotional intimacy and there is no hurry. Couple is instructed to avoid intercourse and any activity that is sexual. The idea is to create a non-demand atmosphere. (reducing performance anxiety, increasing pleasurable encounters). Create a sensual environment. Partners are both givers and receivers (regardless of the Identified Patient (IP)) Gradually build, first touch in general, no genital touch, with and without clothing to focus on sensations from touch, coach them to talk about what they like and what they want/need. During each session the giver listens to the receiver. The receiver progresses to being present (mindful) during the exercise only. Review the assignment at the next session (questions on page 187) Once the couple is comfortable with nonsexual touch, move to erotic and genital touch, again in small increments. The goal is for the couple to experience sexual stimulation as a goal in itself. If desired, then the couple can move to intercourse (no pressure). This can also be done in gradual steps. Use exercises listed as examples for specific disorders.
Using the Miracle Question to distill down the preferred narrative. CBCT is a good example to help couples. Couples need to focus on emotions rather than logical thoughts that keep them stuck in their cycle. Sexual Ignorance: Performance-based, goal-oriented model of normal is damaging to sexual intimacy. Sexual Mythology: Misguided beliefs, misconceptions, and distortions that promote unrealistic standards and rigid expectations. Faculty Cognitions: These can be engrained and automatic. They then can interfere with sexual desire, and limit a range of sexual behaviors (i.e., masturbation). Sexual guilt, anxiety, and shame Counter Faulty Beliefs Psychoeducation CBT Techniques Dealing with Intimacy Fears Underlying and unconscious fears of intimacy can complicate sex therapy (do couple work first) Distance regulation (fears of rejection/abandonment, dependency, anger, emotion, losing control). Sex therapists need to be collaborators with medical practitioners in the treatment of medically related sexual issues and cognitive disabilities Physical Illness: Sexual functioning involves many body systems. Thus, illness can impact sexual functioning. It is best to research the illness and what body systems are impacted by it (it is systemic) before deciding on a course of treatment. Neurological Ailments (affect physical)

Bibliography:
Type: Journal Article
Title: The Use of Emotionally Focused Therapy with Separated or Divorced Couples Le recours à la thérapie centrée sur l’émotion auprès des couples séparés ou divorcés, Author: Allan, Robert; Couples with children who are separated or divorced need to develop a plan for coparenting and the lifelong shared tasks of childrearing. While legally informed programs can offer mediation, these services can miss the underlying conflict that continues to plague postseparation couple relationships and, more importantly, their children. Divorce is a process with multiple transitions for a family, and the couples who separate or divorce may have a history of negative communication patterns that have long corroded their relationship. There is a need to develop a new coparenting relationship that can serve as a foundation for the long-term. The research literature varies in understanding the impact of divorce on children, but there is consistent agreement that parental conflict does affect child maladjustment. Emotionally focused therapy (EFT) is one effective means of working with a couple who are separated or divorced. EFT is an empirically supported couples’ treatment that was developed from attachment, emotion, and systems theories. This article explores the use of Stage 1 of EFT for couples who are separated or divorced, using a case example to further illustrate the model.
Keywords: Need to Read

couples-(hdfs-8876)/readings/@armenticon.title: @armentiConjointTreatmentIntimate2016
couples-(hdfs-8876)/readings/@armenticon.description:
Bibliography: Armenti, N. A., & Babcock, J. C. (2016). Conjoint treatment for intimate partner violence: A systematic review and implications. Couple and Family Psychology: Research and Practice, 5(2), 109–123. https://doi.org/10.1037/cfp0000060 Type: Journal Article Title: Conjoint treatment for intimate partner violence: A systematic review and implications., Author: Armenti, Nicholas A.; Babcock, Julia C.; Journal: Couple and Family Psychology: Research and Practice, Volume: 5, Issue: 2 Pages: 109-123 Year: 2016 DOI: 10.1037/cfp0000060 ISSN: 2160-410X, 2160-4096 Gender-speciﬁc men-only interventions for intimate partner violence (IPV) have had limited success beyond the effects of arrest alone. This review outlines current U.S. state-mandated treatments for IPV, acknowledges how conjoint treatment may better address a subtype of IPV that is not motivated by power and control, examines and reviews previously conducted couples-based treatments, and highlights policy implications and future directions. Empirical ﬁndings and theoretical support for the Duluth model, cognitive– behavioral approaches, and IPV typologies are presented, followed by a systematic review of selected quasi- and true experimental studies on couplesbased approaches for IPV. U.S. state guidelines that absolutely exclude conjoint approaches are overly restrictive, considering the poor evidence of effectiveness for current gender-speciﬁc groups. Further, the theoretical foundations of most men-only groups assume unilateral, male-to-female violence, which does not ﬁt at least one-third of court-involved cases and leaves treatment needs of couples experiencing problematic relationship dynamics unmet. For a carefully screened subset of couples that experience predominantly “situational violence,” conjoint communication and relationship skills training groups may be a viable alternative to the Duluth model and cognitive–behavioral men-only groups.
Keywords: #IPV #Domestic-Violence #Battering-Intervention #Conjoint-Treatment #Situational-Violence "Some U.S. state guidelines are so restrictive that they appear to prohibit anything except a Duluth model intervention." (p. 109) "No true experiments have found the Duluth model to be effective." (pg. 109) "The intervention piece of the Duluth model has minimal impact on reducing recidivism over and above the effect of arrest and probation alone." (p. 110) "Psychologists tried to improve men's group outcomes by incorporating cognitive-behavioral techniques known to be effective in treating other externalizing behaviors, including anger and substance abuse issues." (p. 110) "The outcome statistics on these cognitive-behavioral men-only groups are disappointing, comparable with those of the Duluth model men's group." (p. 110) "No single current battering intervention modality outperforms any other and there is room for improvement in adequately reducing IPV recidivism." (p. 110) Primary Goal of Journal Article: "The primary aim of this review is to introduce the potential utility of conjoint intervention as an alternative approach to both Duluth model and Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) interventions for a certain subset of intimate partner abusers." "Reviewed studies included treatment conditions in which both members of a couple experiencing IPV were involved in direct intervention and follow-up measures obtained from a combination of victims only, both victims and perpetrators or conviction reports." "Beginning in the 1980s, the Duluth model men’s groups were implemented as a deferred-adjudication intervention, prompted by judges so that the influx of new arrests for IPV did not overwhelm jails and prisons." (p. 110) "The Duluth model was based on ideology and field-based interviewing rather than scientific testing." (p. 110) "The Duluth model creators developed the “power and control wheel,” which conceptualizes IPV as one form of abuse to maintain male privilege." (p. 110)
The primary objective is to abandon authoritarian relationships and achieve effective forms of behavior that fall on the “equality wheel,” which fosters an egalitarian mindset within relationships. In this model, re-educating men is the goal." (p. 111) "This model focuses predominantly on maladaptive beliefs held by men regarding women, IPV, and gender stereotypes." (p. 111)
"The Duluth model curriculum posits that the mechanism of change is replacing maladaptive attitudes held by men. Besides using the “Time-Out” technique, it does not provide strategies for functional changes in relationship dynamics." (p. 111) "Like the Duluth model intervention, cognitive–behavioral therapy (CBT) interventions are also typically administered to men in a group setting." (p. 111) "Treatment places the importance of examining and eliminating violent behavior at the forefront." (p. 111) "Violence is considered to be learned behavior and must in turn be replaced by learned nonviolent behavior. Similarly to the Duluth model intervention, this type of intervention seeks to rehabilitate the sole perpetrator of the IPV." (p. 111) "Cognitive–behavioral interventions for IPV outline the functionality of violent behavior, explore the pros and cons of using violence to solve problems, and propose alternative solutions for dealing with antecedents of violence." (p. 111) "These strategies include cognitive restructuring of negative attributions, anger management techniques, and resocialization." (p. 111) "Unlike the Duluth model, cognitive– behavioral interventions adopt an explicit therapeutic rather than psychoeducational stance in an effort to reduce violent behavior." (p. 111) Although there is a proliferation of typologies of IPV perpetrators, rarely is intervention tailored to the needs of specific types of perpetrators. (p. 111) Survey data from a national longitudinal sample suggested reciprocal or bilateral violence, with both partners perpetuating violence against each other, occurs in 50% of U.S. couples reporting IPV, while another study suggested that the rate of couples experiencing bidirectional violence is as high as 60%. (p. 112) Treatment approaches that assume unilateral, male-to-female violence may not address a significant portion of the types of problems that couples present with when seeking treatment. (p. 112) First called Patriarchal Terrorism then to Intimate Partner Terrorism and then to Coercive Controlling Violence Patriarchal terrorism exemplifies men’s systematic use of control tactics against women, which can include violence but also economic subordination, isolation, and threats. (p. 112) Both men and women can perpetuate. (p. 112) This involves severe forms of severe forms of violence with a goal of dominating or controlling one's partner, and is often fueled by positive attitudes about violence in general. (p. 112) Coercive controlling violence is also a hallmark feature of the later coined term 'characterological violence.' (p. 112) A perpetrator of predominantly characterological violence is likely to be violent in all intimate relationships. (p. 112) Common Couple Violence (to Situational Couple Violence) Common couple violence was created to serve as a gender-neutral term, and is thought to result from relationship conflict that leads to violence, rather than patriarchic motivations related to control. (p. 112) Common couple violence, a label that potentially minimized the seriousness of the problem, was changed to situational couple violence. (p. 112) Situational violence includes behavior such as pushing, grabbing, and slapping, and typically occurs with lower frequency. This type of violence is not motivated by underlying desires to dominate and control one’s partner, but rather occurs as a result of situational stressors within a relationship that are repeatedly remedied by using violence as a problem-solving strategy. (p. 112) The manifestation of recurring, bilateral IPV is usually sustained by interactive and dyadic factors, such as distorted emotions, thoughts, and beliefs among intimate partners. Such factors contribute to relationship dysfunction associated with bilateral IPV, and situational violence is its most common form. (p. 112) For couples that experience situational violence, the violence may stop when partners enter new relationships with less volatile partners. (p. 112) Characterological violence is characterized by a pathological desire for power and control, but even levels of coercive control may fall on a continuum. (p. 112) Appropriateness for conjoint treatment will vary depending on levels of coercive violence, and whether characterological or situational features dominate the overall picture of violence. (p. 113) Female victims of violence who had participated in conjoint therapy said that they often felt intimated or afraid in therapy and refrained from sharing these feelings with their therapists. (p. 113) Victim blaming is always a possibility in the context of court-mandated interventions. Men sent to jail or to any type of mandated intervention often blame their female partners for putting them in such a situation. (p. 113) Placing partner-violent men in a group setting can in actuality offer justification from other group members that beliefs about using violence in intimate partner relationships is acceptable. (p. 113) Failure to address dyadic conflict that occurs in relationships may contribute to further perpetration of violence, instead of protect individuals from it. (p. 113) To date, eight studies have tested couples approaches for addressing IPV. (p. 113) One study concluded that conjoint interventions for IPV can be used safely, at least if they are used in conjunction with probation, and especially for couples with alcohol problems. (p. 113) Results from two studies showed that BCT lowered IPV in alcoholic men from 60% to 24% for men who continued to drink following treatment and to 12% for men who abstained from alcohol following treatment. (p. 114) Women who were victims of intimate terrorism/characterological violence would not—and should not—attend conjoint groups. To carefully and systematically designate which couples would be appropriate for conjoint treatment, researchers have created and validated the Situational Violence Screening Tool (SVST). (p. 118) Both men and women are interviewed to rule out controlling behavior, fear, severe abuse, drug and alcohol abuse, and antisocial and borderline personality disorder features. (p. 118) Validated screening tools are a critical first step for identifying situationally violent couples for whom conjoint interventions may be particularly effective. (p. 118) Creating Healthy Relationships Program (CHRP) The CHRP is a 22-week multi-couple group program that focuses primarily on skills including effective conflict management and creating a shared meaning within the relationship. This program is based on the sound relationship house theory, which emphasizes factors that contribute to relationship satisfaction and longevity in committed relationships.
The Sound Relationship House.jpg

couples-(hdfs-8876)/readings/@dohertydis.description:
Bibliography:
Type: Journal Article
Title: Discernment Counseling for “Mixed‐Agenda” Couples, Author: Doherty, William J.; Harris, Steven M.; Wilde, Jason L.; Journal: Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, Volume: 42,
Issue: 2
Pages: 246-255
Year: 2016 DOI: 10.1111/jmft.12132
ISSN: 0194-472X, 1752-0606
This article describes discernment counseling, an approach to working with couples where one partner is leaning toward divorce and the other wants to preserve the relationship and work on it in couples therapy. These “mixed‐agenda” couples are common in clinical practice but have been neglected in the literature. The goal of discernment counseling is clarity and confidence regarding the next steps for the relationship, based on a deeper understanding of each partner's contributions. Sessions emphasize individual conversations with each partner. An analysis of 100 consecutive cases found that about half of the couples chose to start couples therapy in order to reconcile, with most of the rest choosing the divorce path. Longer term follow‐up information is also presented.
Keywords: Need to Read

couples-(hdfs-8876)/readings/@wiebeattac.description: Bibliography: Wiebe, S. A., Elliott, C., Johnson, S. M., Burgess Moser, M., Dalgleish, T. L., Lafontaine, M.-F., & Tasca, G. A. (2019). Attachment Change in Emotionally Focused Couple Therapy and Sexual Satisfaction Outcomes in a Two-year Follow-up Study. Journal of Couple & Relationship Therapy, 18(1), 1–21. https://doi.org/10.1080/15332691.2018.1481799 Type: Journal Article Title: Attachment Change in Emotionally Focused Couple Therapy and Sexual Satisfaction Outcomes in a Two-year Follow-up Study, Author: Wiebe, Stephanie A.; Elliott, Cass; Johnson, Susan M.; Burgess Moser, Melissa; Dalgleish, Tracy L.; Lafontaine, Marie-France; Tasca, Giorgio A.; Journal: Journal of Couple & Relationship Therapy, Volume: 18, Issue: 1 Pages: 1-21 Year: 2019 DOI: 10.1080/15332691.2018.1481799 ISSN: 1533-2691, 1533-2683 Emotionally focused couple therapy (EFT) is an empirically validated attachment based approach to couple therapy. From an EFT perspective, sexual functioning is viewed within the context of an attachment bond, but sexual satisfaction in EFT has not been empirically tested. We examined self-reported sexual satisfaction across 24 months in a sample of 32 couples who received an average of 21 EFT sessions. We found that sexual satisfaction increased across six time points from pre to post therapy and across follow-up (6, 12, 18, and 24 months), and that decreases in attachment avoidance from pre to post therapy predicted increases in sexual satisfaction across time. These findings provide evidence that EFT may help couples improve their sexual satisfaction by reducing attachment avoidance in therapy. How comfortable do you feel discussing about the role of sex between the clients? (Maybe on a scale of 1-10)) “interconnected nature of relationship and sexual functioning in couple relationships on the part of couple and sex therapists generally and in emotionally focused couple therapy (EFT) specifically” (Wiebe et al., 2019, p. 1) “couples EFT resulted in improved sexual desire and a decrease in depressive symptoms” (Wiebe et al., 2019, p. 2) “The goal of the current study is to examine self-reported sexual satisfaction, attachment anxiety and avoidance, and relationship satisfaction among couples receiving EFT and across 2 years after therapy has ended.” (Wiebe et al., 2019, p. 2) “Sex is a way for couples to express affection, explore and experience intimacy, satisfy desire, lessen tension, restore connection after conflict, and shape personal and relational meaning” (Wiebe et al., 2019, p. 2) “Sexual interest and arousal tend to foster interest in forming and maintaining close relationships, including increased self-disclosure, intimacy related thoughts, willingness to make sacrifices for a romantic partner, and greater wanting to resolve conflict in positive ways” (Wiebe et al., 2019, p. 2) “Marital dissatisfaction and ongoing unresolved conflict may also be barriers to quality sexual experiences” (Wiebe et al., 2019, p. 2) “Sexual functioning and relationship functioning are inextricably linked and bidirectionally influential in couple relationships” (Wiebe et al., 2019, p. 2)“higher levels of relationship satisfaction at one assessment wave predicted more positive changes in sexual satisfaction from that assessment wave to the next and vice versa” (Wiebe et al., 2019, p. 2)“changes in sexual satisfaction correlated with changes in relationship quality, and that declines in sexual satisfaction were associated with increased divorce probability.
