diversity/lecture/1.-intro-to-diversity-.title: 3. Understanding Oppression, Identity, and Intersectionality
diversity/lecture/1.-intro-to-diversity-.description:
Crenshaw (1991) McGoldrick & Hardy (Chapter 9) University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019
Kang et al (Unit I) @kangIntroductionWomenGender2017
Almeida & Tubbs (2020) @almeidaDecolonizingCouplesFamily2018
(In Practice) The Four I's of Oppression (In Practice) Decolonizing CFT
Intersectionality
Social Location
Social Constructionism
Power
Privilege
White Supremacy 1
Oppression
Historical Trauma
Cultural Paradigm
Critical Race Theory
Hegemony Any oppressive system has the idea that one group is somehow better than another, and in some measure has the right to control the other group. The idea that one group is better than another group and has the right to control the other gets embedded in the institutions of the society. Institutional oppression does not have to be intentional. The idea that one group is better than another and has the right to control the other, which gets structured into institutions, gives permission and reinforcement for individual members of the dominant group to personally disrespect or mistreat individuals in the oppressed group. Most people in the dominant group are not consciously oppressive. They have internalized the negative messages about other groups, and consider their attitudes towards the other group quite normal. The fourth way oppression works is within the groups of people who suffer the most from the mistreatment. Oppressed people internalize the ideology of inferiority, they see it reflected in the institutions, they experience disrespect interpersonally from members of the dominant group, and they eventually come to internalize the negative messages about themselves. If we have been told we are stupid, worthless, abnormal, and have been treated as if we were all our lives, then it is not surprising that we would come to believe it. This makes us feel bad. Oppression always begins from outside the oppressed group, but by the time it gets internalized, the external oppression need hardly be felt for the damage to be done. If people from the oppressed group feel bad about themselves, and because of the nature of the system, do not have the power to direct those feelings back toward the dominant group without receiving more blows, then there are only two places to dump those feelings - on oneself and on the people in the same group. Thus, people in any target group have to struggle hard to keep from feeling heavy feelings of powerlessness or despair. They often tend to put themselves and others down, in ways that mirror the oppressive messages they have gotten all their lives. Acting out internalized oppression runs the gamut from passive powerlessness to violent aggression. It is important to understand that some of the internalized patterns of behavior originally developed to keep people alive - they had real survival value. On the way to eliminating institutional oppression, each oppressed group has to undo the internalized beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors that stem from the oppression so that it can build unity among people in its group, support its leaders, feel proud of its history, contributions, and potential, develop the strength to challenge patterns that hold the group back, and organize itself into an effective force for social change. The -isms all work to establish a defined norm or standard of rightness under which everyone is judged. This defined norm is backed up with individual and institutional violence which makes the oppression possible. The defined norm is a notion that all of us might accept and promote for various reasons probably connected to a sense of inferiority or economic vulnerability. 'Whiteness as Poverty' argues that law has come to embody and legitimize benefits that accrue to citizens just because they are right. Despite the end to formal racial discrimination in the legal system race matters in how the law is carried out. Due to the embedded racism in American society, Whiteness can be considered a property interest. Right of Possession Right to Use and Enjoyment Right to Disposition Right of Exclusion Critics of Harris' argument suggest that distributive justice sets up harm for the dominant group (in this case whites). Harris argues, "Acknowledging Black identity does not involve the systematic subordination of whites, nor does it even set up a danger of doing so."
Equality Treating everyone the same (aims to promote fairness)
Equity Giving everyone what they need to be successful (may appear unfair) A tendency for people of a particular religion, race, social background, etc., to form exclusive political alliances, moving away from traditional broad-based party politics. Rather than organizing solely around belief systems, programmatic manifestos, or party affiliation, identity political formations typically aim to secure the political freedom of a specific constituency marginalized within its larger context. Members of that constituency assert or reclaim ways of understanding their distinctiveness that challenge dominant oppressive characterizations, with the goal of greater self-determination. Identity politics shifts out moral and political attention from individual wrongful acts against individuals - perhaps motivated by prejudiced attitudes or bigotry - to structural and systematic injustice against social groups. This process of recognizing as social and systematic that was formerly perceived as isolated and individual has also characterized the identity politics of marginalized groups (i.e., racial ethnic minorities and LGBTQ persons) For all these groups, identity-based politics has been a source of strength, community, and intellectual development. This occurs when social structures that create and organize different social groups, e.g., gender and race, interact to produce effects that may not be intended. Example: Domestic violence shelters that do not address the multiple needs of poor women, immigrants, and women of color, plausibly also trans women, e.g., by refusing to admit non-English speaking women. Patterns of subordination often intersect in women's experience of domestic violence. Oftentimes one burden interacts with pre-existing vulnerabilities to create another dimension of disempowerment. This occurs when the political movements working towards justice for different groups, e.g., feminism and antiracism, interact to exclude or marginalize the interests of some subset of the groups, or reinforced another form of injustice. Examples: For women of color anti-racist and feminist political agendas often conflict with one another This is the same for people of color regarding anti-racist and LGBTQ political agendas. Many times the experience of the dominant group within a targeted population shapes the political agenda. Therefore, both agendas fail to acknowledge the additional issue of race, patriarchy, or sexual or gender identity and are often inadequate in articulating the full dimensions of racism, sexism, or heterosexism. A concept that refers to the cultural construction of an identity, including the production and the contemporary critiques of the identity. This occurs when images or tropes are taken to be representative of the group ignore or distort the complexity of the group.
"Representational intersectionality would include both the ways in which these images are produced through a confluence of prevalent narrative of race and gender, as well as the recognition of how contemporary critiques of racist and sexist representations marginalize women of color." (@crenshawMappingMarginsIntersectionality1991, p. 1283) The experience of being a member of more than one social group that cannot be decomposed into the experience of being a member of each. Example: The experience of being a Black woman is not just the experience of being Black and the experience of being a woman. The experience of being a Black woman is a proper compound of the two. Critical Race Theory (CRT) states that, 'Racism and discrimination are matters of thinking, mental categorization, attitude and discourse.' (Stefancic and Delgado, 2012, p. 21) and it challenges the 'ontological and epistemological biases subtly inculcated in the law, policies, or in empirical research that would otherwise hinter contextualization of harm and dysfunction resulting from racial stratification.' (Brown, 2003, p. 294) CRT helps focus our attention on the recursive interactions between institutionalized and interpersonal discrimination. Through the application of CRT to counseling and psychotherapy it is possible to interrogate the Eurocentric, ethnocentric and individualistic ways in which mental health practices are undertaken. Clients in need of psychological support can then be given a safe space for them to explore (in their own vernacular if necessary) their experiences of living in a capitalistic, racist, and misogynistic world.

diversity/lecture/1.-intro-to-diversity-.title: 4. The Impact of Systemic Oppression in Therapy
diversity/lecture/1.-intro-to-diversity-.description:
McGoldrick (Chapter 3 and 4) University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019
Sue et al. (Chapter 4, 5, and 6) University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@sueCounselingCulturallyDiverse2022 When members of the dominant culture impose their standards upon culturally diverse populations without regard for differences. Refers to a belief in the superiority of one's group's cultural heritage over another, and the implications of those standards upon the less powerful group.
Cultural Encapsulation: Counselors who are culturally unaware and who operate in isolation from a broader cultural context.
Cultural Racism: Imagined, constructed, and allusive distinctions (not based on ascribed physical markers) among social groups provide a reasonable basis for racial and ethnic superiority and, therefore, justify incorrectly the systematically and pervasively unequal relations. Belief in the Superiority of the Dominant Group Belief in the Inferiority of Others Power to Impose Standards Manifestation in Institutions The Invisible Veil Internal: Believe they are in control and take responsibility for their own actions. External: Blame external forces for their own circumstances.
People who have Internal Locus of Control believe that the outcomes of their actions are results of their own abilities.
People with an External Locus of Control attribute success or failure to luck or chance, a higher power, or the influence of another person. To produce conditions that allow for equal access and opportunity To reduce or eliminate disparities in education, health care, employment, and other areas that lower the quality of life for affected populations To encourage mental health professionals to consider micro, meso, and macro levels in the assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of clients and client systems. To broaden the role of the helping professional to include not only counselor/therapist but also advocate, consultant, psychoeducator, change agent, community worker, and so on. Critical Race Theory (CRT) states that, 'Racism and discrimination are matters of thinking, mental categorization, attitude and discourse.' (Stefancic and Delgado, 2012, p. 21) and it challenges the 'ontological and epistemological biases subtly inculcated in the law, policies, or in empirical research that would otherwise hinter contextualization of harm and dysfunction resulting from racial stratification.' (Brown, 2003, p. 294) CRT helps focus our attention on the recursive interactions between institutionalized and interpersonal discrimination. Through the application of CRT to counseling and psychotherapy it is possible to interrogate the Eurocentric, ethnocentric and individualistic ways in which mental health practices are undertaken. Clients in need of psychological support can then be given a safe space for them to explore (in their own vernacular if necessary) their experiences of living in a capitalistic, racist, and misogynistic world.
Remediation The action of remedying something, in particular of reversing or stopping environmental damage.
Prevention The action of stopping something from happening or arising.

diversity/lecture/1.-intro-to-diversity-.title: 5. Multicultural Barriers in Therapy and Culturally Competent Assessment
diversity/lecture/1.-intro-to-diversity-.description:
Sue et al (2019) (Chapter 7 and 13) (University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@sueCounselingCulturallyDiverse2022)
McGoldrick & Hardy (Chapter 37) University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Diversity/Diversity/Readings/@mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019
Jones et al (2020) @jonesStandingGapContinued2020
Cultural Formulation Interview (Cultural Formulation Interview)
(Optional) Cognitive Biases Codex
(Optional) Kim Constructive Conversations Model Culture consists of all those things that people have learned to do, believe, value, and enjoy. It is the totality of the ideals, beliefs, skills, tools, customs, and institutions into which members of society are born (Ratts & Pedersen, 2014). Focus on the individual Verbal/emotional/behavioral expressiveness Insight Self-Disclosure (openness and intimacy) Scientific empiricism Distinction between mental and physical functioning Patterns of communication
' Family Systems Theory may be equally as culture - bound as any other form of therapy, and this limitation may be manifested in marital or couple counseling, parent-child counseling, or work with more than one member of a family.'
Family Systems Theory suggests that healthy families: Allow and encourage the free and open expression of emotion. View each member as having a right to be their own unique self (individuate from the emotional field of the family). Strive for an equal division of labor among family members. Consider egalitarian role relationships between partners desirable. Hold the nuclear family as the standard.
High-Context (HC) Communication Anchored in the physical context (situation) or internalized in the person. HC communication relies heavily on non-verbals, and the group identification/understanding shared by those communicating.
Low-Context (LC) Communication Place a greater reliance on the verbal part of the message. Characteristics of communication associated with race, gender, and other group identities often manifested in verbal and nonverbal communication language. 30-40% of what is communicated conversationally is verbal. What is the other 60-70%?
Proxemics Refers to perception and the use of personal and interpersonal space. Example: Physical closeness or distance when communicating
Kinesics The term used to refer to bodily movements Example: Facial expressions
Paralanguage Used to refer to other vocal cues that individuals use to communicate Example: Volume of voice Non-verbal communication tends not to be under conscious control. Non-verbal behavior provides clues to conscious deceptions or unconscious biases. 'Therapists who have not adequately dealt with their own biases and racist attitudes may unwittingly communicate them to culturally diverse clients.' Microaggressions are the 'everyday slights, indignities, and insults committed against marginalized groups because of their membership in those groups.'
The Kim Constructive Conversations Model (KCCM) is a guide to having difficult conversations about important topics with family, friends, and co-workers. The aim is to deepen engagement and mutual understanding in hopes of working and healing together. Informed by evidenced-based theories and tools, the KCCM emphasizes the following: Understanding barriers to constructive conversations Self-awareness and regulation Values as anchors Personal skills development Healing in relationship connection The KCCM Goal Barriers Values Openers Take Action Listen Respond Repeat Use both clinician skill and client perspective to understand the problem Collaborate and jointly define the problem. Jointly formulate a hypothesis regarding the cause of the problem. Jointly develop ways to confirm or disconfirm the hypothesis on the problem, continuing to consider alternative hypotheses. Test out the hypothesis using both the client and the therapist as evaluators. If the conceptualization appears to be valid, develop a treatment plan. If the hypothesis is not borne out, jointly collect additional data and formulate new, testable hypotheses. Deliberate practice is individualized training activities specially designed by a coach or teacher to improve specific aspects of an individual's performance through repetition and successive refinement. Deliberate practice is an evidenced-based method of skill development. Deliberate practice works best when training targets each student's personal skill thresholds or current ability. If a deliberate practice exercise is either too easy or too hard, the student is unlikely to benefit from it. To maximize training productivity, performers follow a 'challenging but not overwhelming' training principle. This means that deliberate practice requires ongoing assessment of the student's current skill and tailoring the difficulty of exercises to consistently target a 'good enough' challenge. Skill Criteria for Attention to Diversity Convey a brief empathic response to a client/family member that indicates you hear their problem or the session content. Reflect on the problem/session content, looking for opportunities to deepen the conversation as it relates to their identity and unique experiences. Ask a question that conveys continued empathy and curiosity about their identity and unique experiences with the problem.

diversity/lecture/2.-race,-religion,-and.title: 6. Examining Spirituality, Religion, and Non-Western Indigenous Methods of Healing and Native Americans and Alaskan Natives
diversity/lecture/2.-race,-religion,-and.description: Requires us to acknowledge positions of privilege and marginalization in the room. Potential Barriers: In general, therapists are less religious than their clients and the population at large. There is a historic divide between science (psychology) and religion In the United States there is a desire to maintain separation between church and state Some therapists avoid the topic to avoid imposing their own beliefs Some therapists lack confidence in how to address religion and spirituality ethically and effectively. An organized system of beliefs, rituals, practices, and community, oriented toward the sacred. Tends to focus on formal organizations with specifically defined and widely accepted beliefs, practices, and traditions. Transcendent beliefs and practices lived out in daily life and relationships. It can be experienced outside religious structure. "A process through which people seek to discover, hold on to, and when necessary, transform whatever they hold sacred in their lives." Spiritually integrated psychotherapy is based on findings in psychotherapy research and the psychology of religion. It is the practice of purposefully assessing clients' spiritual/religious belief systems and worldviews in the context of psychotherapy, while integrating spiritually oriented interventions. Clinical Spiritual Moral Any inquiry about topics commonly related to spiritual themes (i.e., meaning making, coping, social support, and morality) Explore client's worldview and/or personal philosophies Listen for client's use of 'spiritually laden' words Explore client's current experience of congruence Acknowledge client's spontaneous statements of spiritual beliefs' Inquire about their spiritual beliefs and practices Inquire about how they connect spiritual, clinical, and moral dimensions of life. Express agreement with the client's spiritual beliefs or sensibilities when such self-disclosure could be therapeutic. Articulate client's dilemma without giving your own position. Point out contradictions between the client's beliefs and clinical realities or moral issues. Challenge the client's way of handling spiritual beliefs based on your own spiritual, moral, or clinical beliefs. Any method of direct inquiry about a client's spirituality or religion. The purpose of spiritual reflection is twofold: Understand ourselves in our work with clients Understand clients from their own point-of-view Increasing our understanding helps us fulfill the role of spiritually integrated therapists by not placing our beliefs and/or bias onto the client. Questions to consider: How are these clients encountering a search for meaning? How do these clients and their presenting problem represent a theme from religious tradition or spiritual worldview (e.g., hope, reconciliation, pillars of faith) Regarding this case, what is an experience of the sacred/divine/spirit? Spirituality and religion as distinctive concepts Ethical implications of integration religion and spirituality in practice Start with a strong understanding of one's own social location 'Indigenous' describes any group of people native to a specific region. In other words, it refers to people who lived there before colonists or settlers arrived, defined new borders, and began to occupy the land. The term 'indigeneity' has emerged to describe the state of being indigenous or related to Indigenous-ness. There are over 476 million indigenous people living in 90 countries across the world, accounting for 6.2% of the global population: Of those, there are more than 5,000 distinct groups. Healing-informed care is care based on Indigenous wisdom about wellness and what is necessary to heal. Balance Relational Strength-based Healing has been defined as 'transition toward meaning, wholeness, connectedness, and balance.' Holistic: Interconnectedness underlies all of human experience Balance: Because of the interdependencies of all life, achieving and maintaining balance is important both to the individual and the larger group. Moral Code: The physical and metaphysical worlds are linked to a moral code. Respect: Respect of all living things and each other is essential for balance.

diversity/lecture/2.-race,-religion,-and.description:
Has a positive attitude toward and preferences for dominant cultural values
Places considerable value on characteristics that represent dominant cultural groups
May devalue or hold negative views of own race or other racial/ethnic groups Begins to question identity
Recognizes conflicting messages and observations that challenge beliefs/stereotypes of own cultural groups and value of mainstream cultural groups
Develops growing sense of one's own cultural heritage and the existence of racism
Moves away from seeing dominant cultural groups as all good. Embraces and holds a positive attitude toward and preference for his or her own race and cultural heritage
Rejects dominant values of society and culture
Focuses on eliminating oppression within own racial/cultural group
Likely to possess considerable feelings - including distrust and anger - toward dominant cultural groups and anything that may represent them
Places considerable value on characteristics that represent one's own cultural groups without question; develops a growing appreciation for others from racially and culturally diverse groups Begins to question the psychological cost of projecting strong feelings toward dominant cultural groups
Desires to refocus more energy on personal identity while respecting own cultural groups
Realigns perspective to note that not all aspects of dominant cultural groups - one's own racial/cultural group or other diverse groups - are good or bad
May struggle with and experience conflicts of loyalty as perspective broadens Has developed a secure, confident sense of racial/cultural identity
Becomes multicultural
Maintains pride in racial identity and cultural heritage
Commits to supporting and appreciating all oppressed and diverse groups
Tends to recognize racism as a societal illness by which all can be victimized. White is a socially constructed category of 'race' with no biological/scientific foundation
The racial category white only exists in relation to other racial categories
The racial category white was created by white power holders to codify the superiority of white people over others
The definition of white has changed over time and has been (and continues to be) determined by the people in power Structural Advantage A privileged position within society and its institutions for whites. A standpoint from which white people look at [themselves], others, and at society - one that allows [them] to see [themselves] as individuals, as 'just human'

diversity/lecture/2.-race,-religion,-and.title: 8. Gender Therapy
diversity/lecture/2.-race,-religion,-and.description:
The early years: Gender was invisible, implicitly, implicitly binary, sexist, racist, and White cis men were the standard. Late 1970 s (White Feminist lens): Example: White binary, heterosexual perspective. Patriarchy, and sexism. 21st Century: Post modern approach to gender (still binary and biologically determined) Biological Sex Refers to the physical sex characteristics you are born with and develop including genitalia, chromosomes, hormones, etc. Biological sex is generally assigned at birth and is often categorized as male, female, or intersex.
Intersex: Describes variation in sex characteristics, such as chromosomes, gonads, sex hormones, or genitals. 'Intersex,' like 'female,' and 'male,' is socially constructed category that humans have created to label bodies that they view as different from those they would classify as distinctly 'female' or 'male.'
Gender The result of socially constructed ideas about the behavior, actions, and roles a. particular sex performs. Term used to exemplify the attributes that a society or culture constitutes as 'masculine' or 'feminine'
Gender Identity One's innermost concept of self as male, female, a blend of both or neither - how individuals perceive themselves and what they call themselves. One's gender identity can be the same or different from their sex assigned at birth.
Gender Fluid: A person who does not identify with a single fixed gender; of or relating to a person having or experiencing a fluid or unfixed gender identity.
Gender Expression: External appearance of one's gender identity, usually expressed through behavior, clothing, haircut or voice, and which may or may not conform to socially defined behaviors and characteristics typically associated with being either masculine or feminine.
Gender Non-Conforming: A broad term referring to people who do not behave in a way that conforms to the traditional expectations of their gender, or whose gender expression does not fit neatly into a category.
Gender-Expansive: Conveys a wider, more flexible range of gender identity and/or expression than typically associated with the binary gender system.
Transgender: An umbrella term for people whose gender identity and/or expression is different from cultural expectations based on the sex they were assigned at birth. Being transgender does not imply any specific sexual orientation. Therefore, transgender people may identify as straight, gay, lesbian, bisexual, etc.
Gender Dysphoria: Clinically significant distress caused when a person's assigned birth gender is not the same as the one with which they identify. According to the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistic Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM), the term - which replaces Gender Identity Disorder - 'is intended to better characterize the experiences of affected children, adolescents, and adults.' Self of the therapist Locating the self Locating the client Unpacking the gender stories in context Examining the use of power Seeking affirmation Reclaiming self and relationships

diversity/lecture/2.-race,-religion,-and.title: 9. Sexuality and LGBTQ+ Persons in Therapy
diversity/lecture/2.-race,-religion,-and.description:
Gender was invisible, implicitly binary, sexist, racist, and White cis-men were the standard. White feminist lens (i.e., White binary, heterosexual perspective, Patriarchy, and sexism) Postmodern approach to gender (still binary and biologically determined) Fmaily therapy theory rests on normative concepts of the traditional family and idealized conceptions of family relationships. Inequalities in the family associated with gender have been regarded as of little importance to the development of macro theory in the field. The two most influential therapeutic models, psychodynamic and systemic approaches, are each marked by gender bias. Feminist therapy is an integrative approach to psychotherapy that focused on the challenges that women face as a result of bias, stereotyping, oppression, discrimination, and other factors, and how those stressors can negatively affect their mental health. 'Feminist Family Therapy is the application of feminist theory and values to family therapy.' Acknowledge and examine the roles of values in therapy for both the therapist and the client (s). Intentionally introduce a discussion of gender into the therapy process using clinical language and techinques that acknowledge experiences across genders. Assess power inequalities in relationships rather than assuming equity in relationships. Include discussion of individual choice and responsibility in conceptualizations of family dynamics. Honor and appreciate the diversity inherent to families. Consider the clinical implications of interventions on both the family and on individual members of the family. Work actively to reduce power inequalities between therapist and client. (Leslie & Southard 2009) According to intersectional feminists, there is not enough emphasis on the intersection of patriarchy with other factors, such as race, religion, and class. Intersectional feminists argue that other types of feminism assume that all women are exploited in the same way in the family. Self of the therapist Locating the self Locating the client Unpacking gender stories in context Examining the use of power Seeking affirmation Reclaiming self and relationships Pillar 1: Intersectional Pillar 2: Systemic Pillar 3: Relational Pillar 4: Liberatory Pillar 5: Transformative Introduce yourself and pronouns and asking for your client/patient's name and pronouns Gather client/patient information using inclusive language Avoid assumptions around identity, body parts, and sexual practices Gather biopsychosocial/sexual history information End the session by thanking the patient Keeley (2022). Integrative Family Therapy with Transgender, Gender Diverse, and Non-binary (TGDNB) Young People Read peer-reviewed published literature to provide best support and understand terminology. Recognize the family as a key protective factor in mental health outcomes of TGNDB children and work with the whole system. Use the pronouns and name the young person requests you use. This may include checking in at each session and using a different name and pronoun when their family is present if this is more comfortable for them. Explore the power in the system and the political climate in which you are seeing a TGNDB person. Example: Be aware of news articles or the area the person lives in to check about transphobic experiences and/or discrimination Connect TGDNB young people to community and peers to build their sense of connection and reduce stigma and isolation Therapist will need to each out to local services and be aware of local networks This can include online community connection The lesbian, gay, and bisexual identity scale (LGBIS) is a 27-item measure designed to assess eight dimensions of lesbian, gay, and bisexual (LGB) identity that have been discussed in clinical and theoretical literature. The development of the LGBIS is fully described by Mohr and Kendra (2011) Accepting Concerns: Worry relating to potential rejection of one's sexual identity
Concealment Motivation: Being concerned with protecting one's sexual identity
Identity Uncertainty: How uncertain one is concerning their sexual identity.
Internalized Homonegativity: The degree to which to which one rejects their sexual identity.
Difficult Process: How difficult one's sexual identity develop was
Identity Superiority: How favorable one views sexual minorities compared to heterosexual people
Identity Affirmation: The association of positive thoughts with one's sexual identity
Identity Centrality: How central one's sexual identity is to one's overall identity

diversity/lecture/3.-cft-with-specific-p.title: 12. African American and Latinx Populations
diversity/lecture/3.-cft-with-specific-p.description:
A labor acknowledgement is a statement that recognizes that much of the economic progress and development in a geographic area or industry resulted from the unpaid labor and forced servitude of People of Color - specifically enslaved African labor. Labor acknowledgements are one way to 'honor and remember the violent histories and legacies of settler colonialism' and to 'collectively begin to acknowledge the historical labor that has allowed our society to get and be where it is today, then we will continue to struggle to reconcile and redress those histories and legacies.' Terah TJ Stewart
Like most modern day US institutions, Solid Ground benefits from the unaddressed legacy of stolen labor at the foundation of this nation and its vast and inequitable wealth. We respectfully acknowledge our debt to the enslaved people, primarily of African descent, whose labor and suffering built and grew the economy and infrastructure of a nation that refused to recognize their humanity. While the 13 th Amendment to the Constitution technically ended 'slavery' in the US, we know that slavery's ongoing impacts are still felt by countless people forced - through violence, threats, and coercion - to work in the US. We recognize our debt to exploited workers past and present whose labor was and continues to be stolen through unjust practices. We acknowledge our collective debt to the Indigenous peoples of this land whose labor was forced and exploited, the Chinese immigrants who built railroads that allowed for westward American development, Japanese Americans whose properties and livelihoods were taken from them while incarcerated during World War II, and migrant workers from the Philippines, Mexico, and Central and South America who have worked Pacific Northwest farms and canneries. We recognize the immigrant and American-born workers of African, Asian, and Central and South American descent whose labor remains hidden in the shadows but still contributes to the wellbeing of our collective community. We recognize that our economy continues to rely on the exploited labor of incarcerated people, largely people of color, who earn pennies an hour while generating billions in goods and services each year. And we know there are many other people, too numerous to mention, who are prevented from reaping the true value of their labor by unjust systems and cruel practices.
We mourn their loss of life, liberty, and opportunity. We acknowledge that the theft of labor is the theft of generational progress. Nearly all people of color have been robbed of the opportunity and wealth that their ancestors might otherwise have passed on to them. What is the presenting problem?
Indicate if there are 'identified patient (s)'
Who initiated contact and why? In 2022, there were roughly 47.9 million individuals who self-identified as Black (14.4% of the U.S. population)
Black Americans are diverse, presenting through the lens of four groups: Total US Black population
Single-race, non-Hispanic Black people
Multiracial, non-Hispanic Black people
Black Hispanic people Help-Seeking refers to the process of finding support for dealing with relationship distress that occurs between couples. Professional help: Couples therapy is an evidence-based approach to improve marital quality, yet there are hesitancies and barriers to treatment. Other sources: Friends
Family
Church Relationship distress amongst spouses/partners 'Different state from the usual ups and downs of a marriage'
Feeling fundamentally dissatisfied with the relationship
Constant
Features of contempt, withdrawal, violence, and loss of connection
Impacts individual and the system Feeling dissatisfied, upset, 'trapped', stuck in a perpetual cycle, desperate for change Looks different between all couples Broader term Ultimately, unresolved relationship distress can lead to the dissolution of the relationship. Black Shadow: 'Internalized myth of Black inferiority that has conceived and propagated by slaveowners to justify the enslavement of African people more than 400 years ago'
Systematic racism has perpetuated these beliefs, promoting White superiority and Black inferiority
'Systems of Power' highlights two states: Have
Have nots
Social hierarchy
Some people have advantages, and some have disadvantages Remember: Ignoring slavery and the history of our country disempowers African Americans African American couples experience worse relationship quality and are less likely than other ethnic groups to seek professional help
Face unique barriers: Stigma
Representation
Power Dynamics Mistrust and racism is not a 'past' system or issue Vaterlaus et al (2015) Prior to Treatment Stigma 'Weakness' (most significant deterrent) Concerns for cultural sensitivity
Financial inability to pay Hubbard et al (2024) During Treatment Discrimination
Microaggressions
Fears of misdiagnosis "African Americans are more likely to be diagnosed with schizophrenia, while mood disorders often go underdiagnosed." Mussa et al (2023) point out that newlywed African American couples tend ot seek help in alternative ways: Help from God (prayer)
Religious leaders
Friends
Family members Hubbard et al. (2024) 'The Black church,' along with friends and family Black churches emerged furing the time of slavery
History of being a 'safe place' to express cultural heritage, develop community, and organize structure
Entry point for mental health care

diversity/lecture/3.-cft-with-specific-p.title: 14. Older Adults and Person with Disabilities
diversity/lecture/3.-cft-with-specific-p.description:
People age 65+ = 16% of the population in 2019 (51.1 million) Expected to be 21.6% by 2040. Nearly 1 in 4 older adults were members of a racial/ethnic minority population: African American (not Hispanic): 12% Asian American (not Hispanic): 13% Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander (not Hispanic): 10% American Indian and Alaska Native (not Hispanic): 12% Hispanic: 8% Persons identifying as two or more groups: 6% In Ohio persons 65+ represented 17.51% of the population (2,046,320) This represents a 27.31% increase from 2009-2019. 8.3% of persons 65+ in Ohio live below the poverty line. In 2020, a larger percentage of older men (70%) than older women (48%) were married. Of older adults age 65+ living in the community, 61% lived with their spouse/partner in 2020. About 27% lived alone The 2019 median income of older persons was $27,398 ($36, 921 for men and $21,815 for women) In 2019, 4.9 million people age 65+ lived below the poverty level. Another 2.6 million were 'near-poor' The median household income of older homeowners was $36,200 in 2019. In 2020, 9.8 million Americans age 65+ were in the labor force (working or actively seeking work). Consumers age 65+ averaged out-of-pocket health care expenditures of $6,833 in 2019, up 41% from 2009. In 2019, about 1.1 million people age 60+ were responsible for the basic needs of at least one grandchild under age 18 living with them. During COVID-19, between March and April 2020, the unemployment rate for adults age 65+ more than quadrupled. Negative stereotypes and discrimination (ageism) Mental deterioration Some cognitive slowing is associated with normal aging (e.g., periodic minor memory difficulties, such as forgetting names or phone numbers or misplacing objects) About 1 in 7 adults 71+ have dementia Alzheimer disease Elder abuse and neglect Substance abuse Social isolation, depression, and suicidality Please identify the following for Older Adults: Characteristics Strengths Ethnic or Cultural Values What emotional stressors are specific to older adults? What are possible ways to support the client in feeling with these emotional stressors? How can we think about care with older adults as suicide prevention? As clinicians, what can we do to address the physical limitations that an older adult client may face to make sure these challenges do not impede the treatment process? 26% of adults in the US have some types of disability (61 million) 2 in 5 adults age 65 years and older have a disability 1 in 4 women have a disability 2 in 5 non-Hispanic American Indians/Alaskan Natives have a disability Adults living with disabilities are more likely to be obese, smoke, and have heart disease and diabetes. 1 in 3 adults with disabilities 18 to 44 years do not have a usual health care provider 1 in 3 adults with disabilities 18 to 44 years have an unmet healthcare need because of cost in the past year 1 in 4 adults with disabilities 45 to 64 years did not have a routine check-up in the past year. Over 3 million children (4.3% of the under-18 population) in the US had a disability in 2019. The most common disability type among children both years was cognitive difficulty American Indian and Alaskan Native (AIAN) children had the highest rate of childhood disability of all racial groups, at 5.9% in 2019. In the moral model (or religious), disability is seen as having meaning about the person's or family's character, deeds, thoughts, and karma. From this perspective, disability can carry stigma, shame and blame, particularly if the disability is seen as a mark of wrongdoing. It can also be seen as a sign of honor, faith, or strength (although this is less common) The moral model is very prevalent worldwide and is often depicted in the media The Medical model views disability as resulting from an individual person's physical or mental limitations The Medical Model focuses on find a 'cure' or making a person more 'normal' The Medical Model uses the terms 'Disability,' 'Disease,' 'Dysfunctional,' 'Disorder' to categorize type of symptoms, differences in mechanisms, below average based on standardized measure of functioning, that causes challenges in life. “Pasted image 20240410205740.jpg” could not be found. This model 'proposes that what makes someone disabled is not their medical condition, but the attitudes and structures of society. It is a civil rights approach to disability.' If modern life was set up in a way that was accessible for people then they would not be excluded or restricted Based on basic human rights principles, "It recognizes that disability is a natural part of human diversity that must be respected and support in all its forms. People with disability have the same rights as everyone else in society," and disability, "must not be used as an excuse to deny or restrict people's rights" Using both models, we can begin to see people with disabilities correctly: as human. We must consider how we can become better allies for individuals with disabilities by ensuring that society is accessible (Social Model) We must examine how we interact with and view people with disabilities.. We must ensure that our policies and practices support the Human Rights Model and encourage full inclusion and participation for individuals with disabilities Therapist make the environment comfortable for their clients.
The Tilt Parenting Podcast: a top podcast about learning disabilities, special education, ADHD, autism, giftedness, twice-exceptionality, and more.
Caregiver Action Network: the nation’s leading family caregiver organization working to improve the quality of life for the more than 90 million Americans who care for loved ones with chronic conditions, disabilities, disease, or the frailties of old age.
Franklin County Board of Developmental Disabilities (FCBDD): Services are provided for children from birth to age 21 who have developmental delays and disabilities.
The Ohio Center for Autism and Low Incidence (OCALI) serves families, educators and professionals working with infants, preschool and school-age children and adults with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and low-incidence disabilities – including hearing impairments, visual impairments, multiple disabilities, orthopedic impairments and other health impairments. Parents raising children with Autism encounter more psychological distress, financial strain, worries for the child's future, and adaptation problems than those parents of children with typical developments The qualitative research will present experiences of parents raising a child with Autism during the pandemic and provide clinical recommendations.
Solution-Focused Therapy for 6 mothers of children with Autism in TX Identified 4 major themes: COVID impacts Financial strain Relational strain Emotional strain Uncertainty with the pandemic Proactive Advocacy Not enough (parental role strain) Supports Instrumental Informational Emotional Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS-15) (5-7 minutes to administer) “Geriatric Depression Scale Short Form English Scoring.pdf” could not be found. Can be used with people who have a cognitive disorder (such as in beginning of stages of dementia) PHQ-9 (normed, because likert scale, it is not as accessible) Depression in Older Adults Scale (DIAS) (commonly used in hospital settings, has fewer questions, removed questions that would make it difficult for someone who is medically hospitalized) Asks yes or no questions (great if person is not feeling well or has a cognitive impairment) Asks questions such as, "I can enjoy my life even when things are sometimes difficult." "I tend to worry a lot." Hospital anxiety and depression scale (HADS) Cornell Scale for Depression in Dementia (CSDD) “Cornell Scale for Depression in Dementia.pdf” could not be found. Screening tool for identifying a person's vulnerability to depression in the context of dementia May be good for people for mild or moderate Given by caregiver, answers questions about person's mood or belief system. Starts by interviewing Is the caregiver noticing behavioral disturbances? Are they noticing physical signs? Changes to cyclical behaviors? Discuss with caregiver concerns of possible depression, "I'm concerned you may be experiencing depression, let's find a provider that specializes in working with older adults." How to start conversation when concerned Start conversation in calm, straight-forward, compassionate way Describe what you observed Can I help you connect with people who can help? Due to added caregiving responsibilities that are necessary for individuals with disabilities, members of families affected by disabilities have an increased prevalence of physical, psychological, and relational distress. Parents, spouses, and siblings of children with disabilities experience higher rates of mental health concerns such as anxiety and depression. Caregivers have higher rates of health problems and reports a variety of physical symptoms such as migraines, heart conditions, and sleep problems. The mental and physical health effects lead to reports of decreased quality of life and general wellbeing. Many of the adverse physical, mental, and relational health effects described by family members of individuals with disabilities are compounded by a lack of social support. Families often explain that there is a notable deficit in available social support, which they generally attribute to two main reasons: Family members’ lack of free time to socialize with friends and family due to the added caregiving responsibilities Societal stigma associated with disabilities that may be attributed to personal shame and embarrassment of family members or the disapproval and ostracization by others Clinicians working with families affected by disabilities can support caregivers by connecting them with appropriate online platforms to increase social support, which acts as a protective factor against the harmful effects of caregiver stress and burnout.

diversity/readings/@mcgoldrickrevisionin.title: @mcgoldrickRevisioningFamilyTherapy2019
diversity/readings/@mcgoldrickrevisionin.description:
Bibliography:
Type: Book
Title: Re-visioning family therapy: addressing diversity in clinical practice, Editor: McGoldrick, Monica; Hardy, Kenneth V.; Publisher: Guilford Press,
Location: New York, NY,
Year: 2019 ISBN: 978-1-4625-3973-4
"A leading text for courses that go beyond the basics of family systems theory, intervention techniques, and diversity, this influential work has now been significantly revised with 65% new material. The volume explores how family relationships--and therapy itself--are profoundly shaped by race, social class, gender, religion, sexual orientation, and other intersecting dimensions of marginalization and privilege. Chapters from leading experts guide the practitioner to challenge assumptions about family health and pathology, understand the psychosocial impact of oppression, and tap into clients' cultural resources for healing. Practical clinical strategies are interwoven with theoretical insights, case examples, training ideas, and therapists' reflections on their own cultural and family legacies"-- Provided by publisher
Keywords: Need to Read

diversity/readings/@suecounselingcultura.title: @sueCounselingCulturallyDiverse2022
diversity/readings/@suecounselingcultura.description:
Bibliography:
Type: Book
Title: Counseling the culturally diverse: theory and practice, Author: Sue, Derald Wing; Sue, David; Neville, Helen A.; Smith, Laura; Publisher: Wiley,
Location: Hoboken, NJ,
Year: 2022 ISBN: 978-1-119-86190-4
"For over four decades, Counseling the Culturally Diverse: Theory and Practice (CCD) has been considered the "gold standard" in culturally competent mental health care. Its cutting-edge presentation of multicultural counseling and therapy (MCT) is used in an overwhelming majority of graduate training programs in counseling and clinical psychology, and it has produced generations of culturally sensitive mental health practitioners. It now forms the multicultural knowledge base of licensing and certification exams at both the masters and the doctoral levels in psychology. In 2021, Social Science Space identified the book as one of the most important works across social science disciplines that has contributed to the ongoing need to understand, analyze, resist, and dismantle racism, bias, and bigotry. In essence, CCD has become a "classic" in the field of mental health practice, and leads the profession in the theory, research, and practice of MCT. CCD upholds the highest standards of scholarship, and is the most frequently cited source in multicultural psychology and mental health. The expert and global perspectives of the four co-authors, each active researchers and practitioners in the field, strengthen the newly minted ninth edition of CCD. As a result, instructors will note the continued fresh, scholarly, and exciting perspective in the content of CCD, as it continues to rank as the most up-to- date text in the field"--
Keywords: Need to Read

ethics-(7770)/lecture/8.-accreditation-a.title: 8. Accreditation and Legal Issues
ethics-(7770)/lecture/8.-accreditation-a.description:
The idea of first year student being paired up with a second year therapist to help guide. Working with agencies? No surprises act: Giving clients an estimate about how much they are going to pay for services Struggle with terminating services. As long as file is open, you are legally their therapist. Case is closed because once the case is closed you are no longer their therapist. They can always come back. What will be different for you when we are ready to move on? What does it need to be life for this to end? We make a mistake of not planting that seed early on. When clients start thinking of me as a person, such as asking questions. When you are no longer in the therapist role, when you stop becoming a person's therapist and become a person to them. They begin to see you as yourself rather than a therapist. If you have not scheduled within 30 days, we would terminate and close their case. They can always call back. Purpose of accreditation: Ensure the quality of marriage and family therapy programs. Accredited programs meet or exceed all standards for accreditation. Standards for Accreditation: Version 12.5 Outcome Based Education (You have to show that your people are meeting target): Vs input based (You offer these courses, your people are confident). 360 Quality and Improvement Review Process
Start with Program goals, then student learning outcomes, and then targets for those outcomes. Review and gather data to show that you are meeting the targets or not and what you are doing to change the program to allow students to meet the SLO's If programs are accredited, licensure boards typically accept that they meet the educational requirements and client contact contact hour requirements for licensure (again, typically, always check with the state board) State of Ohio -> 500 hour requirement
Board -> 300 hour requirement Set standards for what adequate education and training is in the field. Protect students in those programs, knowing that they are able to be licensed in their state with that education, and protects the public in general, knowing that a therapist who graduated from an accredited program has the education and training needed to provide the service. Legal Age for Marriage in Ohio: 16 What are the Marriage Age Requirement Laws in Ohio? While females in Ohio may get married as young as 16 with the consent of both parents, only a juvenile court (in limiting cases) may consent to a marriage involving a male under 18. Same-sex marriage has been 'legal' and recognized in Ohio since 2015. Parentage: A man is presumed to be the natural father of a child in certain circumstances, including: The man and the child's mother are or have been married to each other, and the child is born during the marriage or is born within 300 days after the marriage is terminated.
An acknowledgement of paternity has been filed pursuant to Sec. 3111.23
The term 'Punative Father' means a man, including one under age 18, who may be a child's father and to whom all of the following apply. He is not married to the child's mother at the time of the child's conception or birth. He has not adopted the child. He has not been determined, prior to the date a petition to adopt the child is filed, to have a parent and child relationship with the child by a court proceeding or an administrative agency proceeding. He has not acknowledged paternity of the child pursuant to Sec. 3111.21 to 3111.35. Understanding Divorce and Custody Issues: Dissolution vs. Divorce: Dissolution is when both parties can agree on all matters pertaining to separation (i.e., no fault divorce).
Divorce is when both parties can't come to an agreement. To get a no-fault divorce, you need to state in the Complaint for Divorce that 'that the parties are incompatible,' or 'the parties have been living separate and apart without cohabitation for 1 year.' The grounds of being incompatible can be defeated if your spouse denies incompatibility.
The fault-based grounds for divorce are bigamy, willful absence of the other party for 1 year, adultery, extreme cruelty, fraudulent contract, gross neglect of duty, habitual drunkness, imprisonment in a state or federal prison at the time of filing, and when the divorce decree of another state does not use any of these, since they had complexity to the process by requiring proof. If parties don't agree about custody agreements, the judge will decide based on child's best interest: The wishes of the parties,
The wishes of the child, if the judge interviewed the child in private, The child's adjustment to home, school, and community,
The mental and physical health of all persons involved, You may get subpoenaed, good idea to contact attorney and ask. If private practice, have attorney on retainer, The party more likely to honor and facilitate parenting time rights,
Whether either party failed to make all child support payments, including arrearages,
Whether either party or a household member was a perpetrator of child abuse or neglect, or a violent or sexually oriented offense involving a member of the family,
Whether either party has continuously and willfully, denied the other party's rights to parenting time in accordance with an an order of the court,
Whether either party has, or has plans to, establish a residence outside of Ohio. Other Considerations: The ability of the parties to cooperate and make decisions jointly,
Each party's ability to encourage contact between the child and the other party,
Any history of, or potential for, child abuse, domestic violence, or parental kidnapping,
The geographic proximity of the parties to each other, The recommendation of any guardian ad litem of the child Child support is determined by reference to the Ohio Child Support Guidelines and includes a chart to calculate the child's needs based upon the combined income of the parties. For example, if the combined income of you and your spouse is $96,000 Recommend learn the laws around divorce and custody in the state you are located in. Don't. (I am not unbiased) (There are training programs for this)
If you decide you want to do that work, then you are not also the therapist for the parties involved. Sometimes you may be asked to testify based on the work you have done with one of the parents, do your best not to. You can put that into your consent form, although might not be considered a legal document. Whenever there is a divorce with custody agreements about children, then you need to review those custody agreements and get the consent of parents who share custody with their children. If a parent has sole custody then their consent is enough. If there is shared custody, then both parents must provide consent to treatment, unless there is a stipulation in the custody agreement that says otherwise. You can work with child and parent of up to 6 session without consent. Can apply for social work and counselor jobs. 2022 Median Pay: $56, 570 60-65 with Masters, as you get your I, increases
Children's is hiring and typically hire. Thriveworks (private practice), OhioGuidestone (Take a look at them during placement fair) Typical Entry-Level Education: Master's Degree
Work Experience in a Related Occupation: None
On-the-job-Training: Internship/residency
Number of jobs, 2022 71,200
Job Outlook, 2022-32: 15% (Must faster than average) As a licensed MFT in Ohio, you are mandated to report a colleague you believe to be practicing unethically. Our ethics code also suggests that we abide by our state regulation and report alleged unethical conduct. You could be asked to leave the program if you do not keep up on your notes. TherapyNote only takes 10-15 minutes. You have 48 hours, but the goal is 24 hours. SOAP (Subjective (what was I thinking, what was happening, process); Objective (we showed up and discussed, if assigned homework); Assessment (things of the process); Procedure (What we are doing next time or next session)). No use of jargon, think of client getting the note, concerned something may have legal ramifications, Applying standard of care to these couples, feels straight forward but you can get hung up. MOST IMPORTANT THING IS TO HAVE A THERAPY NOTE If you are dating a client, it does not always mean you lose your license. They could require you to do more practicum and classes. (Remediation procedures in place) What to do if you are accused?

ethics-(7770)/lecture/10.-hippa-and-hite.title: 10. HIPPA and HITECH
ethics-(7770)/lecture/10.-hippa-and-hite.description:
Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA): Makes health information portable so that individuals can maintain health insurance between jobs. Ensure that health care plans and providers are held accountable with regard to keeping health information private Provides federal privacy protections for physical and mental health information known as protected health information (PHI).
Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH): Increases patient rights over their PHI Increases restrictions over disclosure of PHI Increased fines for HIPAA violations Funding for compliance audits HIPPA/HITECH Compliance: If you furnish bills, receive payments for health care, and any transactions are sent in electronic form, you are a covered entity (CE). If an organization creates, receives, maintains, or transmits PHI on behalf of a CE, it is considered a business association of the CE. If you take self-pay only and do not bill insurance, then you might not be a CE, but HIPAA is becoming a standard of care. State Laws and our Ethics Code are actually more stringent than HIPAA around the confidentiality and privacy of therapy in terms of notes, diagnoses, etc. When working for a CE, have to provide a Notice of Privacy Practices, a disclosure about what information can be shared and what can’t be. Biggest concerns are about electronic medical records and breaches of confidentiality Use only HIPAA compliant software which encrypts and has lots of safeguards against hackers including back-ups etc. HITECH compels CE’s to notify anyone effected by a breach of confidentiality within 60 days of the discovery of the incident with a risk analysis. Follow your agencies rules and regulations and report any breach to supervisor, they should then follow what ever procedure is set up.
Telehealth: Standards of care: (Know your state's regulation) In Ohio, relaxed the rule that you have to see the person in-person at least once. Now you have to have a way to identify that you are treating the person they say they are (some form of picture ID). Have to have procedures for emergencies (local therapists, or other agencies that can respond if client is suicidal/homicidal). Have to have a signed consent form. Can't practice across state lines Billing? Must be HIPAA compliant. Zoom is not HIPAA compliant, have to have a platform that is. Most studies suggest that telehealth is just as effective as in-person therapy. For CFT's, how do you pay attention to process via telehealth? Need to find creative ways to engage all members of the system on a small screen.
