pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/6.-asses.description:
Read Patterson et al. Chapter 4 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Patterson et al. Chapter 10 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Patterson et al. Appendix @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Gerhart Chapter 11 Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017
Read Gerhart Chapter 12 Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017 Read Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS Framework) Read and Review: “Media/Clinic Media/(CAMS) Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality.pdf” could not be found.
Read (https://www.etr.org/blog/deescalation-techniques-coping-with-students-clients-coping-with-our-lives/)
Watch (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h1xGjKuDAaQ&ab_channel=DianeR.Gehart%2CPh.D.)
Watch (https://youtu.be/R2PSExM-NhULinks to an external site.)
Watch (https://youtu.be/6B9Kqg6jFeILinks to an external site. Review Diagnostic Assessment Outline:“Diagnostic Assessment Outline.pdf” could not be found. Review Non-Violence Agreement: “Non-Violence-Agreement (4).pdf” could not be found. Review Intimate Justice Scale: “Intimate-Justice-Scale.pdf” could not be found. Review Gender Inclusive Power and Control Wheel: “PowerandControlWheel- gender inclusive.pdf” could not be found. Review LGBT Power and Control Wheel for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Trans Relationships: “LGBT power and control wheel.pdf” could not be found. Review Safety Plan How-To Guide for Clinicians:“Safety Plan How-To Guide for Clinicians.pdf” could not be found. Review Cultural Formation Interview: “APA_DSM5_Cultural-Formulation-Interview (3).pdf” could not be found. Review How to Create a New Client in Therapy Notes: “How To_ Create a New Client in Therapy Notes.pdf” could not be found. MAKE SURE TO COMPLETE OBSERVATION FORM AFTER OBSERVATION Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD7): “GAD-7 (1).pdf” could not be found. Patient Health Questionnaire: “PHQ9.pdf” could not be found. Experiences in Close Relationships Scale - Short Form (ECR-SF):“ECR-S.pdf” could not be found.
Description: https://novopsych.com.au/assessments/formulation/experience-in-close-relationship-scale-short-form-ecr-s/Links to an external site. How do we not make assumptions on how people feel? We can only guess, but that can come off. - Don't want to jumpt to conclusions. Allow the client to describe it. Can you tell me what it looks like for you? Use open ended questions. using states like "I have heard people describe this before, how does it feel for you? What is just suicidal ideation? What if Types of Clinical Assessment: Two broad approaches to assessment: Systemic Approach Postmodern Approach Formal Assessments: Formal assessment involves the use of tools such as tests, questionnaires, checklists and rating scales. Formal assessments often have data to determine their reliability and validity. Examples: Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7 Questionnaire (GAD7) - Individual
GAD-7 (1).pdf Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ9) - Individual
PHQ9.pdf Experiences of Close Relationships Scale - Couple Informal Assessments: Unstructured: Writing or drawing activities Journals Games Observation Structured: Checklists Rating Scales Interviews Questionnaires The mental status examination is a structured assessment of the patient's behavioral and cognitive functioning. In general, the components of a mental status exam include descriptions of the following: Appearance: Casual dress, normal grooming and hygiene. Attitude: Calm and cooperative General Behavior: Unusual movements or psychomotor changes Speech and Language: Normal rate/tone/volume and without pressure Emotions: Reactive and mood congruent, labile, tearful, blunted, normal range, depressed, constricted, flat Mood: Euthymic, irritable, elevated, anxious, depressed Thought and Perception: Goal-directed and logical or disorganized Suicidal ideation: passive, active, plan? Homicidal ideation: passive, active plan? Hallucinations or delusions during interview Cognition Orientation: oriented to time, place, person, self Biopsychosocial Model: “Screenshot 2023-09-27 at 10.25.48 AM.png” could not be found. A Biopsychosocial Assessment is an assessment typically conducted by therapists at the beginning of therapy, which assesses for biological, psychological, and social factors that can be contributing to a problem or problems with a client. Biopsychosocial Assessments enable therapist to diagnose and effectively treat clients. Tasks and Process of Assessment: Make Initial Contact Develop a collaborative therapeutic relationship Use a bio-psycho-sociocultural-spiritual assessment: Person-in-Environment Defining problems Assessing safety Accessing and appreciating patient/clients' strengths Assess systems collaboration issues and strengths Expand awareness and perspectives Assess goals Biopsychosocial Assessment Areas: Demographic Information (Age, Ethnicity, Religion, Relational Status, Referral Status, etc.) History of the Presenting Problem Psychiatric History Trauma History Family Psychiatric History Medical History Medication Use Substance Use Family History (Family of Origin, Relationship with Parents, Siblings, etc.) Social History Spiritual/Cultural Factors Developmental History Educational/Vocational History Legal History SNAP (Strength, Needs, Abilities, Preferences) Other Important Information Guiding Principles for Assessment: A systemic view: Everything is connected Foundational importance of bio-physiological, psychological, sociocultural, and spiritual domains in relation to multiple service systems A strengths-based perspective Assessment as an ongoing process Regular screening and tracking during sessions of the following: Health status Mobility Wellness Exercise Nutrition Sleep Ensure that client has primary care physician Communicate with primate care physician or other health providers as needed. General Psychological Issues: Cognitive skills and ability (e.g.. thought process, problem-solving/decision-making skills) Behavioral skills Emotional competencies: Affect regulation Capacity for relating Motivational factors Overall mental status Risk Assessment Specific Mental Health Concerns: Depression Anxiety Substance Use Appropriate referral if needed Ongoing communication between external providers (collaboration of care) Risk Assessment includes consideration of psychological and social factors as part of a comprehensive review to capture client needs, and to assess their risk of harm to themselves or others. Assessments often aim to categorize patients as at high, medium, or low risk Examples of risk areas include: Suicidal ideation Homicidal ideation Child abuse/neglect Intimate partner violence Physical health issues or crises Inability to care for self or others Animal abuse Substance abuse Important factors: Level of risk Intent to act Plan to act Means to act Risk and protective factors Assessing Strengths: Personal and Relational Strengths: Bio-physiological Psychological Sociocultural Spiritual 'Strengths' of the problem/symptoms Strengths in systems collaboration Exploring the 'Strengths' and Potential 'Contributions' of the Problem When was the last time that you realized that the problem was helpful to you? If your problem has a voice, what do you think it is trying to share or communicate with you? How might the problem be helpful to you? If we could get rid of the problem, what might be some aspect of it that you might want to retain? Useful Questions for Assessing Strengths: What has been helpful so far? What are some of your successes? What are the achievements that you are most proud of having accomplished? What little things are you doing that make life a little better for you? What kinds of things do people compliment you on? When have you stopped doing something that was difficult for you to stop? When have you made an important change in your life that was difficult to make? When have you broken a habit that was hard to break? Outcomes of Assessment: Problems: Bio-psycho-sociocultural-spiritual perspective Problem and attempted solutions specifically and behaviorally described (SOLVABLE). Goals: Desired future outcomes Specifically and behaviorally described (ATTAINABLE) Professional and the patient/client mutually agree to the described problems and goals. Treatment plan and interventions based on mutual consensus of problem and goal David A. Jobes, Ph.D. Creator of CAMS Framework Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS) It is a therapeutic framework for suicide-specific assessment and treatment of a patient's suicidal risk. It is a flexible approach that can be used across theoretical orientations and disciplines for a wide range of suicidal patients across treatment settings and different treatment modalities. Every session of CAMS intentionally utilizes the patient's input about what is and is not working. All assessment work in CAMS is collaborative. The clinician's honesty and forthrightness are key elements. The CAMS clinician endeavors to understand their patient's suffering from an empathic, nonjudgemental, and intra-subjective perspective. The clinician never shames or blames a suicidal person for being suicidal. Evidence-Based Psychological Treatments for Suicide: Three evidence-based (randomized controlled trials) interventions and treatments that are designed to directly target suicide at risk. Dialectical Behavioral Therapy (DBT) Cognitive Behavior Therapy (CBT): Suicide Prevention (CT-SP) and Brief CBT. Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS) Suicide-Specific Brief Interventions: Evidence-Based (Random Controlled Trial): Teachable Moment Brief Intervention (TMBI): A one-time intervention 2 dats after an attempt. Motivational Interviewing: In-patient settings Crisis Response Planning & Safety Planning (6 Steps) Attempted Suicide Short Intervention Program (ASSIP): 3 Sessions in-patient settings Malpractice Liability, Competent Practice, and Cases of Suicide: Know the three 'pillars' for reducing malpractice liability (i.e. malpractice wrongful death torts): Foreseeability: Treatment Planning: Follow-Up/Follow-Through:

pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/7.-intro.title: 7.  Introduction to Telehealth
pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/7.-intro.description:
Read Caldwell (2017) @caldwellUsingScalingFacilitate2016
Read Holland (2021) @hollandRiskAssessmentCrisis2021
Read Maheu (2018) @maheuFrameworkInterprofessionalTelebehavioral2018
Read Suler (2001) @sulerAssessingPersonSuitability2001
Watch '20+ Telehealth Tips from a Certified TeleMental Health Therapist' (https://youtu.be/8Eotw2mbHkk%20) How do we balance knowing what we know and what our clients can teach us Dialectic, expertise and balancing feedback. Don't take things personally from clients. How do you What would be the ideal way to approach feedback? How is it realistic? How would you like me to respond? How can we acknowledge it being received. Ethical Concerns and Telehealth: Remember our ethical imperatives for in-person therapy. Rely on common factors Rely on our professional standards of practice AAMFT Code of Ethics Coalition for Technology in Behavioral Science (CTiBS) TBH Competencies Know and adhere to legal guidelines (federal and state) Continue education and training. Seek supervision. Assessing Appropriateness for Telehealth: Conduct an initial assessment of the client to determine if telehealth is appropriate. Conduct ongoing assessment to determine appropriateness to receive services via teletherapy throughout the court of treatment. Consider: Current Mental and Emotional Status Is the treatment model conducive to telehealth? Is the current delivery of the service effective? Does the client have the technological ability and resources necessary? A client may be inappropriate for telehealth if: Recurrently experiences, or is likley to experience, crises or emergencies. Is a suicide risk, or likely to become a suicide risk. Has a history of previous non-suicidal self-injury. Is violent, or likely to become violent. Risk Management in Telehealth: Suicidality Homicidality Child Abuse/Neglect Intimate Partner Violence Animal Abuse Physical Health Issues or Crises Obtain your client's physical location at the start of each session. Complete Address Make, Model, Color of Car Nearest Physical Location Obtain a client's emergency contact at initial intake and review regularly Physical Location Distance from the Client (nearest ETA) Obtain contact information for local emergency resources: Local police and fire departments Local Crisis Centers Family Pediatrician/PCP National Crisis Numbers Safety Assessment: Is it safe for them to return or remain home> Are there weapons in the house? Are the children in danger? Is the violence escalating? Are they unwilling to complete a safety plan? Is their situation too severe and they require a higher level of care? The most important intervention a therapist can use when working with a suicidal client is compassion for the pain they are in and patience in listening to their story. What is a Safety Plan? A safety plan is a prioritized written list of coping strategies and sources of support developed by a clinician in collaboration with clients who are at high risk for suicide. A safety plan is not a 'no-suicide contract,' which is not recommended by experts in the field of suicide prevention. As generally used, no-suicide contracts asks clients to promise stay alive without telling them how to stay alive. Safety Planning: Safety planning incorporates elements of four evidence-based suicide risk reduction strategies: Reducing Access to Lethal Means Teaching Brief Problem Solving and Coping Skills Enhancing Social Support and Identifying Emergency Contacts Using Motivational Enhancement to Increase likelihood of Engagement in Further Treatment Assessing for Child Abuse on Video Session: On a video call, observe how the house appears: Look for ongoing sings that go beyond messiness. Is perishable good sitting out after multiple calls? Is there an absence of food or do family members appear to be losing weight? Are there signs of pests or rodents? Do children appear significantly unkempt or not bathed? Look for signs of increased frustration. This is a time of great stress for parents, ask questions to see how well a parent is coping. "How are things going with the kids?" "What are you getting to do during the day?" Speak with the Children: Ask for time to speak with the children along. Observe their reactions to who and what is around them. What is their level of focus? Do they seem particularly stressed or emotional? Is their behavior atypical? Be Understanding: If a parent is expressing desperation, be empathetic. It is normal for parents to express frustration with statements such as 'being over it' or 'giving up.' Red flags for a listener include: Over rigidity Persistent expression of negative emotions Inability to see beyond their immediate concern Extreme frustration that suggest possible escalation to physical aggression Telepresence and Virtual Professionalism: Telebehavioral health (TBH) professionals can demonstrate how to apply appropriate techniques to maximize therapeutic atmosphere in both physical and virtual environments as well as minimize distraction and interruptions. Professionals can show how to approximate an in-person relationship and foster spontaneity through TBH. Creating a Virtual Office: When setting up your virtual office, we must consider the following: Physical Location Privacy Lighting Comfort Where is your home based or online office located physically? Is it near a power source? Is there a way to 'close the door' to your office? (i.e., is there at least a door between your office space and other common areas in your location?) Is it a high traffic area? How can you create a distraction free environment? Turn off anything that makes noise. A sign outside the door can help remind others not to make noise during the session. Avoid a space with lots of clutter on the desk. Be mindful of what is behind you in the camera's view. How can you create a quality video image? Make sure you are well lit. Are there shadows being cast on my face? Am I lit well enough to see me clearly? Find the best source of lighting. Overhead light (may not be the best) Desk Lamp Single Floor Lamp (Often Good: 4-5 ft, bulbs point up to the ceiling) Make sure your camera is well placed. Eye level with the camera straight at you (ideal). Practice good posture (use the picture-in-picture) How can you create a therapeutic environment? Find an office space with minimal distractions or a solid color background. Be mindful of clothing to limit distractions. Solid colors are best Avoid busy patterns Avoid large jewelry and hats Before the First Session: Provide clear instructions to your clients about how to join the session. Become aware of common technical problems that could arise and how to trouble shoot for these problems. If possible, host a test call. Both therapist and client obtain contact information in case of technology failure. During the First Session: Ask for initial feedback for sound and video quality Allow for more time for interviews Remain attentive Keep eyes on camera Avoid distracting behavior and excessive movement Turn off anything that makes noise Remain in view of camera at all times Be mindful of possible delays and lags in video Speak slowly and deliberately Understanding Telebehavioral Health Competencies: Clinical Evaluation and Care Virtual Environment and Telepresence Technology Legal & Regulatory Issues Evidence-Based & Ethical Practice Mobile Health Technologies Including Applications (Apps) Telepractice Development Telebehavioral Health Competency Levels: Novice: Identify and describe issues Conduct basic screening List pros and cons of using various technologies Protect security, privacy, and confidentiality Educate clients about fundamental TBH, laws, rules, regulations, ethical requirements, policies, procedures, assessments, interventions, standards and communication styles. Proficient Authority: Demonstrate the basics of using computers, remote patient monitoring, social media and mobile health and the issues related to recommending the use of apps. Discuss how to legally and ethically market their own services online.

pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/8.-treat.title: 8. Treatment Planning
pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/8.-treat.description:
A treatment plan refers to a written document that outlines the proposed goals, plan, and methods of therapy. Diagnosis
Presenting Problem
Treatment Goals
Treatment Objectives
Treatment Strategy/Interventions
Frequency and Duration of Treatment
Evaluation: Measuring Progress and Outcomes Goals are the building blocks of the treatment plan. They are designed to be specific, realistic, and tailored to the needs of the person in therapy. The language should also meet the person on their level. Treatment Goals must be SMART
A SMART goal provides structure and a sense of direction that supports members in increasing their chances of achieving their treatment goal (s). Specific
Measurable
Achievable
Relevant
Time-Bound Goals are often broken down into objectives to support the person in therapy through the process of taking small, achievable steps toward the completion of the larger goal. Goals usually also include the various techniques and interventions the mental health professional will implement to support achievement of the larger goal. Frequency refers to how often will they attend - weekly, every two weeks, once a month, once, as needed, etc.
Duration refers to how long someone will attend 1 week, 1 month, 3 months, etc. Is the client achieving progress? Measured in several ways: Client self-report
Therapist observation
Informal and Formal Assessment Case conceptualization is a report based on information gathered, organized, and assessed to provide an explanation of client’s behavior or presenting problem. It is the therapist perspective on the case. Theory guides our case conceptualization or our view of the problem. Family systems theory Specific theoretical approach or model Case Conceptualization is not a diagnosis in itself There is a diagnostic component Introduction of the client
Presenting concern
Background information
Systemic assessment
Genogram Listen to client's story and presenting problem. Gather information about how they understand their world
Obtain demographic information
Explore social, cultural, and historical context
Assess client's strengths and coping skills Assess for risk, create a problem list
Diagnose
Apply theoretical orientation and hypothesize about the nature of the problem
Develop goals
Plan interventions Apply theory to information gathers in initial interview
What is your theoretical understanding of the client?
What patterns of thinking, feeling, and action need to be addressed?
How does theory inform the treatment goals?

pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/9.-clini.title: 9. Clinical Writing and Documentation
pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/9.-clini.description:
Clinical documentation is a tool that guides the clinical process and aids in measuring outcomes. Client documentation provides the content required for clients' clinical chart, also known as the medical record or health record. Medical/Health records are legal documents and are protexted under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA) When you meet with a client for the first time, you gather background information and outline policies and procedures for the therapy process. An Intake Note allows you to document a full biopsychosocial evaluation of your client, including the presenting problem, a mental status exam, and history. Is also allows you to document other important events that occur during the intake process, such as obtaining informed consent for treatment, reviewing practice policies and procedures, and discussing important topics like confidentiality and billing. Limits of confidentiality
Payment procedures
Telehealth Procedures
Contact outside of the session
Risks and benefits of therapy
Cancellation policies
Reasons for coming to therapy
Previous experiences with therapy
How current problems are affecting the client
Medical history
Current medications
Substance use history
Any previous mental health diagnoses
Mental health history (including hospitalizations, SI, HI)
Family History
Employment
Trauma history
Education history
Cultural Background
Support system
Any assessments they've taken
Legal history
Strengths
Religious/spiritual concerns
Mental Status Exam A treatment plan refers to a written document that outlines the proposed goals, plan, and methods of therapy. A Treatment Plan must be completed prior to completing a Progress Note for a client's first scheduled Therapy Session after their intake session. This is because the Diagnosis, Objectives, and Frequency of Treatment are initially recorded on a client's Treatment Plan and pull forward into subsequent Progress Notes for the client. Diagnosis
Presenting Problem
Treatment Goals
Treatment Objectives
Treatment Strategy/Interventions
Frequency and Duration of Treatment
Evaluation: Measuring Progress and Outcomes Progress notes, are the official record of each therapy session. They're meant to be shared with other members of the client's care team and insurers when requested. Progress notes include information such as diagnoses, interventions used, and progress toward treatment plan goals. SOAP Notes:
Subjective: This section details the session from the client's perspective. It includes information like the client's feelings on their progress or lack of progress, the effectiveness of therapy, and goals for the session. Objective: Next, you'll list your own observations of the client's overall demeanor, attitude toward therapy, how they responded to the interventions you used, and any results you achieved. Assessment: In this section, you'll digest the information from the above two secions and record your professional opinion. Include data like your clinical impressions and evaluations of their progress towards treatment goals. Plan: Here's where you'll lay out your course of action moving forward. What do you plan to address in the next session, and what interventions do you plan on using? How does your plan relate to the client's short and long-term treatment goals? Key Things: All clinical documentation including progress notes should be completed within 24–48 hours of the session or non-clinical event. Failure to complete notes in a timely manner is an ethical violation. Progress notes and other clinical records are legal documents. They fall under several laws and protections. Notes and other forms of documentation should be written with care. Write your notes 'as if the client is standing over your shoulder.' Psychotherapy notes are defined as notes recorded by a health care provider who is a mental health professional documenting or analyzing the contents of conversation during a private counseling session or a group, joint, or family counseling session that are separated from the rest of the individual's medical record. Therapist may keep psychotherapy notes separate from patient's records. Written by mental health professional to document/analyze conversations during counseling session. The following information is not to be included in process notes: Medication
Start and stop of sessions
Modalities and frequency of treatment
Results of clinical tests
Summaries of diagnosis, functional status, treatment plan, symptoms, prognosis, and progress to date. Contact notes are non-clinical notes used to document communication between a staff member and a client or a client's contact. If you intend to charge for the communication, a Contact also creates a billing line item. The termination note is a non-billable note template used to record a client's discharge from treatment. A discharge note, also called a termination note, is a written summary held in the client's chart of what happened during the time the client was in your care. The discharge note also includes recommendations for future mental health care needs and referrals to help the client follow through on these recommendations. To write a discharge note we should include: Reasons for termination, including referrals to new providers
Symptoms at the time of intake
Initial reasons for seeking treatment
Diagnosis
Treatment goals, past and present
Modalities and interventions used and how the client responded Progress (or lack thereof) made during treatment Tips on Writing Clinical Documents: Client Progress Notes are Legal Documents
Use the correct words (avoid jargon)
Beware of acronyms and abbreviations
Keep your entry professional
Acknowledge that Progress Notes contain confidential information and should be kept in a secure location.

pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/10.-inte.title: 10. Intervention and Treatment Skills
pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/10.-inte.description:
Referral
Making Contact
Planning
First Session
Inter-Session Analysis and Planning
Follow-Up Sessions (Focused on Assessment, Information Gathering, Rapport Building, Initial Treatment Planning) Follow-Up Sessions Working the Treatment Plan
Interventions
Assessment of Progress
Review of Goals and Time Efficiency 'Muddy Middle Phase' Interventions are intentional behaviors or 'change strategies' introduced by the counselor to help clients implement problem management and move toward goals. Self-Disclosure
Normalizing
Reframing
Using Questions
Providing Support
Confronting
Crisis Stabilization
Psychoeducation Psychoeducation refers to the process of providing education and information to those seeking or receiving mental health services, such as people diagnosed with mental health conditions (or life-threatening/terminal illnesses) and their family members. Briefing the patients about their illness
Problem-solving training
Communication training
Self-assertiveness training Information about a specific diagnosis or problem. See the handouts section below for further resources.
Explaining and revieing treatment options and combinations of treatments such as medication and CBT. Explaining psychological concepts and the interventions that will be used in your specific approach to counseling or psychotherapy. Assessing a client's psychoeducational needs to identify gaps in the client's life skills. Value clarification to ensure your client understands what gives their life meaning. Emotional literacy training. Boundary clarification and boundary setting to develop and maintain healthy relationships while moving on from unhealthy situations.
Conflict resolution skills to help maintain relationships.
Coping with grief following relationships' breakdown, divorce, bereavement, or job loss. Developing parenting skills. Reframing involves presenting an alternative possible explanation, interpretation or perception of an experience. This new interpretation may then facilitate positive change. Common reframes are related to negative or blaming statements, negative behaviors of system memebers, or difficult family situations. There are three main goals of reframing: The first is to change the meaning of the problem(s) or behaviors. Reframes provide system members with a potentially different direction to proceed in their situation. Successful reframes connect system members together through the creation of a joint system focus.

pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/11.-work.title: 11. Working with Families with Children
pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/11.-work.description:
The presenting problem is a window into the system dynamics that contribute to the problem. Parents are your allies as well as members of the system. This gives them a unique position. Keep in mind ages and stages. When parents bring children to therapy, they are likely experiencing helplessness. They are tired. Don't go it alone! Assessment and treatment often require referrals. Allow everyone's voice to be heard. The family life cycle theory was first developed around 1960. This theory uses the term Family Life Cycle to describe the emotional and intellectual stages you pass through from childhood to your retirement years as a member of a family. In each stage, you face challenges in your family life that allow you to build or gain new skills.
Infancy → Early Childhood → Middle Childhood → Adoelscence → Young Adulthood → Middle Age → Later-Life → Aging Space: Flexible use of space Safety: Physical space limits and discipline Shared Responsibility: Collaboration with children and parents Co-therapy Expectations: Time management Structure Parental Psychoeducation Connection with the School System Boundaries Autonomy Identity Technology Limits and Discipline "The systematic use of a theoretical model to establish an interpersonal process wherein trained play therapists use the therapeutic powers of play to help clients prevent or resolve psychosocial difficulties and achieve optimal growth and development. " Child play therapy is a way of being with the child that honors their unique developmental level and looks for ways of helping in the 'language' of the child - play. Licensed mental health professionals therapeutically use play to help their clients, most often children ages 3 to 12 years, to better express themselves and resolve their problems. Real Life & Nurturing Doll House Dolls for Doll House and Furniture if able Medical Kit Baby Dolls and Bottles Tools Fake Food and Utensils Phone Fake Money and Jewelry Mailbox (Optional) Blocks or Legos Roll Up Road Rug and Cars Ambulance Binoculars Jail and Police Car Acting Out & Aggressive Fake Weapons Aggressive Animals and Puppets Destroyable Items (such as phone book or egg cartons) Creative & Emotional Release Various Art Supplies and Construction Paper Play Dough and Tools Dress Up Items and Magic Wand Other Puppets Heroic/Villain Figures Therapeutic Games Kinetic Sand Allow for exploration of real-life experiences including cultural values, traditions, and roles. Facilitate contact with the child by gaining the child's interest and attention. Permit reality testing/limit setting. Provide the opportunity for development of self-control. Facilitate exploration of the self and others. Allow children to express their needs symbolically (without any need for verbalization) Provide for expression of a wide range of feelings Provide opportunities for insight/self-understanding Allow for creative expression Toys should also be durable, simple, and easy to operate, allow for success and are fun.

Diamond et al (1999) @diamondAlliancebuildingInterventionsAdolescents1999
Boundaries Autonomy Identity Technology Limits and Discipline (Micucci, The Adolescent in Family Therapy)
Multidimensional Family Therapy
Strategic Family Therapy (Brief)
Functional Family Therapy Interactional Change: Interventions in which therapists allow or prompt family members to interact with one another naturally to assess family dynamics, and direct in-session interactions among members to promote more effective ways of relating. Relational Reframe: Therapist efforts to transform symptom-focused and/or adolescent-focused perceptions of clinical problems into a new understanding of those problems as being fundamentally relational, thereby motivating families to pursue changes in family relationships as the primary clinical solution. Adolescent Engagement: Interventions in which therapists join with adolescents by seeking their unique points of view, and foster treatment engagement by presenting family therapy as an opportunity to address personally meaningful issues within and outside the family. Relational Emphasis: Interventions that focus on the family as a whole, assessing systemic attributions and processes and intervening to improve overall family functioning.

pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/13.-work.title: 13. Working with Couples
pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/13.-work.description:
Read Patterson Chapter 9 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Taibbi (2022) Chapter 12 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022 Telebehavioral health (TBH) professionals can demonstrate how to apply appropriate techniques to maximize therapeutic atmosphere in both physical and virtual environments as well as minimize distraction and interruptions. Professionals can show how to approximate an in-person relationship and foster spontaneity through TBH. When setting up your virtual office we must consider the following: Physical location Privacy Lighting Comfort Where is your home based or online office located physically? Is it near a power source? Is there a way to 'close the door' to your office? (i.e., is there at least a door between your office space and other common areas in your location?) Is it in a high traffic area? How can you create a distraction free environment? Turn off anything that makes noise A sign outside the door can help remind others not to make noise during the session Avoid a space with lots of clutter on the desk Be mindful of what is behind you in the camera's view How can you create a quality video image? Make sure you are well lit. Are there shadows being cast on my face? Am I lit well enough to see me clearly? Find the best source of lighting. Overhead light (may not be the best) Desk lamp Single floor lamp (often good; 4-5 ft.; bulbs point up to the ceiling) Make sure your camera is well placed. Eye level with the camera straight at you (ideal) Practice good posture (use the picture in picture) How can you create a therapeutic environment? Find an office space with minimal distractions or a solid color background. Be mindful of clothing to limit distractions Solid colors are best Avoid busy patterns Avoid large jewelry and hats Learning to relax Be present Joining Empathic listening Curiosity Attending skills Assessment Diagnosis Case conceptualization Treatment planning Theory based interventions Couples therapy is dyadic. The relationship is the client. It is important to have 1 (no more than 2) shared goals for therapy. Both partners must participate. We need to establish clear treatment objectives. Session 1: Initial Intake Session (80 minutes) Session 2: Individual Subsystem Session (Partner 1) (50 minutes) Session 3: Individual Subsystem Session (Partner 2) (50 minutes) Session 4: Conjoint Couples' Session (50 minutes) Session 5 and Beyond: Conjoint Couples' Session Welcome and Introductions Orientation to Therapy and the First Session Review Informed Consent and Clinic Policies Question and Answer Risk Assessment Initial Understanding Presenting Problem Begin Development of Treatment Goals Reflection and Wrap-Up Welcome and Quick Overview of the Session Remind clients of no secrets policy. Risk Assessment (Past and Present) Assess for Infidelity Review Individual Functioning Understanding Presenting Problem from the Individual Perspective Continue Development of Treatment Goals Reflection and Wrap-Up Before this session, therapist should have an initial systemic hypothesis and theory based conceptualization of the case. During the session: Provide clients with a summary of information gathered in sessions 1-3. If necessary, discuss new information or secrets shared in sessions 2 and 3 Review and confirm treatment goals and objectives Goals and objectives must be SMART Continue assessment as needed for individuals and/or relationship Begin intervention or working phase WORK the treatment plan Continue to evaluate your hypothesis and conceptualization between sessions Interventions should be based on the client's presenting problem as well as your theoretical conceptualization

pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/14.-indi.description:
Read Taibbi (2022) Chapter 7 Read Taibbi (2022) Chapter 13 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022
Read Patterson Chapter 12 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018 Intake and Interview Referral Making Contact Planning First Session Inter-Session Analysis and Planning Follow-Up Sessions (Focused on Assessment, Information Gathering, Rapport Building, Initial Treatment Planning) Follow-Up Sessions Working the Treatment Plan Interventions Assessment of Progress Review of Goals and Therapy Effectiveness "Muddle Middle Phase" Determining the appropriate time to end therapy This could be one or more sessions Creating a plan for post therapy Engaging in evaluation of therapy effectiveness Termination also represents the closure of the professional Relationship between client and therapist Notify clients several sessions in advance Summarize the therapy experience Wish clients well Possible memento - can be co-created Review ethical requirements - in public won't speak first Provide referral and emergency numbers Open Door Policy Clients have achieved goals Clients have discontinued services Clients have discontinued contact Insufficient Progress Planned Pause in Treatment Client referred Clinician closing practice/graduation Mental Status Exam (MSE) Risk Assessment Biopsychosocial Assessment How does this person's behavior exist in the current pattern of relational contexts? What is the role of the diagnosis in maintaining balance in their current relationships? How do the person's behaviors and physiology interact and reciprocally affect one another? Diagnostic labels may be used as a source of identity eclipsing strengths, capabilities, resilience, power, and agency. We can use alternative client-generated descriptions of the problem and identify to access their strengths, power and agency.

pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/15.-self.title: 15. Self-Care and Self of Therapist Revisited
pre-practicum-(8189.11)/lecture/15.-self.description: Read Taibbi (2022) Chapter 14 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022 Create a consistent plan to engage in mentally, emotionally, physically, and spiritually nourishing activities. Schedule restorative rejuvenation when anticipated stress. Prepare a list of emergency strategies for unanticipated stress. Meet regularly with peers or colleagues for support. Evaluate counselor-specific professional, perceptual, and personal challenges to self-care. Record and review successes. Include self-compassion as an essential element of self-care. Protect your mornings (or whenever you wake up) Less cortisol, more intentionality Go outside perspective, context and something larger than this. Be active In body, mind, and spirit. cultivate relationships Those that are edifying and healthy Nurture gratitude What is one thing, right now, that is going well? Detox: if navigating addictions be wise and safe Spend time with animals low stress hormones and high comfort Simplify: (less is more) be mindful of decision Fatigue and cognitive overload Admire art the gift of feeling transported Laugh Pure humor = a sustaining force Foster Humility and Extend Grace Self-righteousness and hubris = unhelpful Sleep To cleanse and repair brain and body Clarify intentions: How can i refrain from causing harm, how can I contribute meaningfully?

pre-practicum-(8189.11)/readings/@patter.title: @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
pre-practicum-(8189.11)/readings/@patter.description:
Bibliography: Patterson, J., Williams, L., Edwards, T. M., Chamow, L., & Grauf-Grounds, C. (2018). Essential skills in family therapy: From the first interview to termination (Third edition). The Guilford Press. Contribution:: Author: Patterson, JoEllen Author:: Williams, Lee Author:: Edwards, Todd M. Author:: Chamow, Larry Author:: Grauf-Grounds, Claudia Title: Essential skills in family therapy: from the first interview to termination Year: 2018 Citekey: @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018 Type: Book Publisher: The Guilford Press Location: New York ISBN: 978-1-4625-3343-5**Essential skills in family therapy: from the first interview to termination[!Abstract] This book focuses on students, a pragmatic approach to treatment, regard for multidisciplinary perspectives, and respect for the influence of families on clients. Chapter 1 identifies concerns that new therapists frequently have, such as building confidence in their clinical work. Chapters 2-6 follow the usual time sequence of therapy--from initial contact with clients, to comprehensive assessment, to treatment planning and intervention. Chapters 7-10 deal with specific clinical situations based on presenting problems and the nature of client families. We examine major issues and approaches for working with children and adolescents, older adults, couples, and families that are struggling with serious mental illness. Chapter 11 highlights some common obstacles all therapists encounter, and provides concrete ideas on how to get unstuck when treatment is not progressing. Chapter 12 focuses on an often overlooked part of therapy--termination. In Chapter 13, we conclude the book by looking at emerging issues within family therapy" While family therapy offers a unique and important perspective in clinical work, much of what goes on in treatment shares common assumptions with all therapies. assessing the appropriateness of a family therapy treatment for a specific problem is an essential clinical skill. It is important to be able to recognize when a problem is outside the scope of a family therapist’s practice (or skill level) and could best be treated by another mental health professional or in tandem with another healthcare professional. A growing focus on treatment teams and multidisciplinary treatment approaches means that therapists must increasingly attend to the biological component of the biopsychosocial model and learn to collaborate with other healthcare professionals. Beginning therapists frequently experience feelings of inadequacy and insecurity about their clinical abilities Therapists and supervisors alike need to see confidence issues from a developmental perspective Paradoxically, the more one learns about how to do therapy, the more one realizes how much one doesn’t know. Although the intensity of these feelings and the ways of coping will vary from therapist to therapist, every beginning therapist struggles to some degree with these feelings. This disclosure helps the beginning therapist to accept that these struggles are developmentally appropriate rather than a sign of being unsuited for the profession the therapist–client relationship is inherently therapeutic. A therapist doesn’t need to do something for clients to have a positive experience. early experiences in seeing clients often involve a steep learning curve It takes time, however, to gain enough experience so that many situations become familiar. examine if distorted cognitions or unrealistic expectations are contributing to their fears or struggles with confidence. Beginning therapists can struggle with perfectionistic tendencies or critical self-talk The only pathway to becoming an experienced therapist was to go through the learning process that he was going through Experienced clinicians indicated that after 5–7 years (or about 5,000–7,000 hours) of clinical experience, they had encountered most clinical issues or problems several times. The intense feelings of anxiety and being overwhelmed that are common in the beginning generally subside after 1–3 months of seeing clients. Therapists trained in individual therapy generally go through three stages of development when learning to do family therapy. In the first stage, they focus on acquiring the skills necessary to work with families. In the second stage, they learn to apply systemic theory to their clinical work, and in the third, “self of the therapist” stage, they focus on more personal issues in relationship to their clinical work The initial skills stage is characterized by the therapist trying to figure out what to do with clients. This focus then shifts in the theory stage to how to think. In the final stage, the therapist focuses on the use of self in being with a family. Beginning therapists report feeling overwhelmed by the experience. Many report going home after seeing clients and crying, while others report that the stress results in headaches, difficulty sleeping, stomachaches, or changes in appetite. Learning to relax and be present in the therapy room with clients is a good place to start. A solid assessment and effective treatment hinge on the therapist’s ability to listen and attend to the client’s story, and to show the client that he or she is understood. Beginners can learn to replace their anxiety about “doing something” with relaxed curiosity and empathy. This approach leads to useful questions and inquiries, which is where therapy begins. The therapeutic relationship is a necessary but not always sufficient ingredient for change. To be effective, interventions must be rooted in a clear understanding of family dynamics. “I know I should be focusing on the process, but I feel like I’m stuck in the content.” Beginning therapists are able to develop good insights and hypotheses, but will have difficulty connecting these pieces together into a coherent picture or treatment plan Many therapists find it helpful to adopt a particular theoretical orientation for conceptualizing cases Explore how the therapist-as-self is both an asset and a liability in therapy. Many of our personal experiences can become catalysts for new ideas and understanding in therapeutic work Therapists’ unresolved issues or “growth areas” can become impediments in therapy. The growth and insight derived from working on these issues can provide the perspective necessary to make constructive use of life experiences in therapy. Thinking (or even obsessing) about clients is something that tends to subside with time and experience. One reason for this change is that the therapist gradually gains a greater sense of clinical mastery by virtue of experience. Therapists learn to balance objectivity and emotional involvement with clients. therapists learn how to construct an emotional boundary The potential for burnout among beginning therapists exists because of several factors. Learning to do therapy can be demanding. Therapists have other stressors outside of their clinical work The courses or clinical work may raise personal issues for you as you learn to do therapy. To avoid burnout, practicing good self-care is essential Taking time for yourself seems counterintuitive when faced with an overwhelming number of tasks to accomplish, but the time lost is often made up by being able to work with renewed energy and efficiency. (many therapists are willing to give this advice to their clients but have difficulty following it themselves.) Be willing to set limits. As therapists gain experience, they often will become more willing to set some limits on their availability, giving them some protected time for themselves. You also need a strong social support network Being with family and friends outside the field will allow you to temporarily escape the demands of being a beginning therapist. Connecting and obtaining support from your peers within your program is invaluable Keep the “big picture” in mind and recall the benefits of being a therapist. Keep the following ‘reminders’ at hand:** Becoming a therapist takes time. This is an opportunity for you to be a learner; you are not expected to be an expert. Becoming an effective therapist takes several years of training. Make sure you take care of yourself. Use constructive means for stress reduction. Develop resources for support from other students, peers, and colleagues. Self-doubts are normal. Be patient with yourself, focus on the positive, and pay attention to the developmental tasks of becoming a therapist. Use the skills that brought you to the field. While you are learning lots of new theory and material, continue to pay attention to your intuition, your desire to work with others, and your natural abilities. The first contact is about to take place, and it can easily make or break a future collaboration where healing work can be done. One of the most critical points in the therapeutic experience: the period before therapy ever begins. During this fragile period prospective clients decide if they want to risk going to therapy. It is not uncommon for families to be at their wit's end when they finally decide to seek treatment or are referred and call for an appointment. Chances are they're worn out, fed up, and feeling hopeless. Individual family members may differ remarked For therapists and clients alike, beginning therapy can elicit feelings of fear, excitement, and nervous anticipation. Each client will take you on a different journey. In the first stage, the therapist welcomes the clients to therapy. The goal of this stage is to do introductions and put the clients at ease. Administrative issues are addressed in the second stage. The purpose of this stage is to ensure clients have a clear understanding of the therapy process, including confidentiality, videotaping, and fees. The goal-setting phase. Here the therapist learns what the clients hope to accomplish through therapy. The time devoted to goal setting will also depend on the number of clients being seen. Soliciting everyone’s perspective on goals within a family will generally take longer than working with an individual. Being able to establish goals for therapy is a realistic expectation. Assessment phase, which typically extends beyond the first interview. Therapist needs to accomplish several important tasks to make the initial interview successful. At each stage of the initial interview, you should be working on building your relationship with your clients. Important assessment information may also come out at any point in the first session, even before the therapist has begun a more formal assessment phase. The most crucial task of therapy is to successfully join with your clients.
- Joining means that clients feel a sense of connectedness with you, which usually arises when they feel you understand, respect, and care about them. Joining is both a technique (developing rapport) and an attitude. - It is the foundation for future work. Failure to successfully join with your clients will hamper all of your efforts, from assessment to treatment.
- Failure to join with clients can lead to Premature Termination (PT) of therapy. - The therapist missed an opportunity to connect with the client and create a safe environment for therapy to take place. - Joining is a process that should be carefully attended to throughout the entire initial interview. - When you begin the session, you should attempt to put your clients at ease given that they are most likely anxious about coming to therapy. - Ideally, you will be able to identify something you have in common with your clients that will help develop a sense of connection. - Joining also takes place at other points throughout the initial interview. - Highlight Reflective listening, maintaining direct eye contact, or leaning forward can also reinforce for your clients that you are interested in them and concerned about what they are saying. Concluding the initial interview with a positive message for your clients can be another way to strengthen your connection. - Highlight Although skills to facilitate joining can be learned - Highlight developing a relationship with another person cannot be reduced to a recipe or set of techniques. - Highlight who you are is the greatest asset you bring to therapy. Your personality, attitudes, life experiences, and compassion become a part of and help create the relationship. - Highlight therapist characteristics can create a barrier to developing a connection. Therapists who have prejudices or negative preconceptions - Highlight about people based on race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status, or religious orientation will likely have difficulty establishing a connection with clients who have these characteristics. - Highlight you should be vigilant in assuring that personal issues or prejudices do not interfere with your developing a relationship with your clients. - Highlight One of the early tasks in an initial interview is to address administrative issues so clients understand the therapy process. - Highlight the therapist who is attuned to the process and not just the content when handling administrative issues may discover important opportunities for assessment or even intervention. - Highlight need to be informed not only of the confidential nature of therapy, but also of the possible exceptions to confidentiality - Highlight It is best practice to cover confidentially both orally and in writing with your client. The consent form for treatment - Highlight should include what is and what is not kept confidential in therapy. - Highlight Therapists working with couples and families must also consider how confidentiality among family members will be handled. - Highlight The therapist must address the extent to which information obtained during these individual sessions will be kept confidential or shared with other family members. - Highlight offer clear guidelines as to the bounds of confidentiality at the beginning of therapy. - Highlight You may want to consult with other individuals or institutions connected with particular cases, such as previous therapists, psychiatrists, physicians, teachers, lawyers, courts, or parole officers. - Highlight need to have clients sign a release of information form, - Highlight to permit communication between you and the other parties. - Highlight The signatures of all participants in therapy are required for the release of information. - Highlight If others contact you about your clients, you should not even acknowledge that they are in therapy unless you have obtained the appropriate release of information. - Highlight obtain a written release of information before discussing a case. - Highlight Therapeutic issues may arise when discussing confidentiality with clients. - Highlight You can tell your clients that you regularly consult with your supervisor, and that videotaping allows your supervisor to witness firsthand what happened in therapy. - Highlight “two heads are better than one.” - Highlight videotaping allows you to review what happened in previous sessions and perhaps have a new insight, - Highlight recording a session gives the therapist the option to replay part of the session for clients. - Highlight You should inform the client who will view the recordings, emphasizing that videotapes are considered confidential information. - Highlight recordings are not kept permanently, but are regularly erased or recorded over. - Highlight Clients should be asked to sign a form giving their consent for videotaping sessions. The form should - Highlight outline the purpose of the videotaping, who will view the recordings, and what will happen to the recordings after therapy is completed. - Highlight Some clients may be reluctant to be videotaped. - Highlight You should carefully explore what is behind their reservations. - Highlight You should pay careful attention to clients who are insistent about not being videotaped given they are the exception rather than the rule. These clients often have sensitive information that they wish to protect or keep secret. - Highlight If therapy will include live supervision or the use of observing/ reflecting teams, discuss this with your clients. - Highlight helpful to allow clients, at their request, to meet supervisors or team members who observe the sessions from behind the one-way mirror. - Highlight It is difficult to assign a monetary value to therapy, and therapists often feel uneasy about charging fees while acting in a helping role. Therapist anxiety about fees can easily be transferred to clients and can create conflict and stress in therapy. Comfort in handling fees will increase with therapeutic experience and confidence in your ability to provide a worthwhile service. - Highlight There is a business aspect of the therapy relationship and discussing fees should be handled in a business-like manner. - Highlight the client is purchasing a service. - Highlight Most programs or clinicians establish a minimum fee and then work within a range. - Highlight ou should discuss acceptable forms of payment, when the fee should be paid, and the fee for late cancellation or “no-show” appointments, if applicable. - Highlight useful to have a written agreement that discusses the fees and policies regarding fees. - Highlight third-party payers limit the number of sessions, or the types of presenting problems or diagnoses they will reimburse. - Highlight If a third-party payer is involved, the therapist should verify insurance coverage at the outset of therapy. Issues that need to be addressed may include provider eligibility, annual deductibles, rate of reimbursement, limitations on the number of sessions, or types of treatments covered. Usually a DSM-5 diagnosis will need to be assigned to the insured patient. - Highlight As with other administrative issues, working out the details for payment can be part of the diagnostic process and help to clarify the family’s expectations of and responsibilities for therapy. - Highlight Generally, free services tend not to be valued by clients. A fee, even a small one, provides some incentive to make effective use of services. Paying a fee also indicates that the therapy has value to the client. - Highlight therapists may be required to discuss with clients their professional qualifications. - Highlight Many agencies and practitioners have clients read and sign an informed consent statement that generally includes a brief description of what therapy is, including the potential risks, such as being asked to examine painful issues. - Highlight define clients’ expectations for what therapy will accomplish and how it will be conducted. This is essential to ensure that clients’ needs are compatible with what you, as the therapist, can or are willing to offer. - Highlight The first step in defining expectations is to ask your clients what they would like to accomplish through therapy. - Highlight How can I be helpful to you?” or “What are you hiring me to do? - Highlight Clients hope that you will be able to fix these problems. Individuals will often say what they want to eliminate - Highlight and have a harder time articulating what they want - Highlight If possible, encourage your clients to describe desired changes in positive language (what will be happening) rather than in negative language (what won’t be happening) - Highlight It is important that each family member is given the opportunity to be heard when discussing problems and goals. This will help in joining with each individual. - Highlight you may discover there is disagreement about the problem itself or who has the problem. - Highlight You don’t want to anger the person who talks excessively, but if you fail to interrupt this behavior, other family members may lose faith in your ability to lead the session. - Highlight In defining goals, a number of challenges can arise. Your clients may identify multiple problem areas, with little distinction of priorities. - Highlight you will need to obtain your clients’ perspective on the relative importance of their problems. - Highlight “Of the issues you have presented, which is most important, and which is least important?” - Highlight your clients may not have a clear idea of what the problem is or what their goals for therapy are. - Highlight may need to contract for a limited number of sessions to explore and define problem areas and goals. - Highlight Another potential problem is that clients may have unrealistically high expectations or goals. - Highlight Setting goals may be further complicated by the unstated agenda of a client, one that he or she feels is not appropriate to disclose. - Highlight Sometimes, even the clients may not be totally aware of their reasons for seeking therapy. - Highlight Alternatively, individuals in couples or families may define goals that initially appear incompatible. - Highlight In these situations, you may need to creatively reframe the goals in such a way as to make them compatible or link them together. - Highlight Once you have a clear understanding of what your clients want or expect from therapy, you need to decide whether it is appropriate for you to take on the case. - Highlight you must assess whether the case is within your scope of practice, that is, whether the clients are expecting help for issues that would be considered appropriate for a family therapist to treat. - Highlight The scope of practice is defined for therapists by the laws that license or certify therapists in their state. - Highlight If the case falls outside your scope of practice, you will need to refer your clients to an appropriate professional. - Highlight you need to assess if the case falls within your scope of competence. - Highlight do you have the necessary skills, training, - Highlight or experience to effectively treat the issues? - Highlight If not, you need to refer the clients to another therapist who has the appropriate skills or qualifications. - Highlight you may be able to treat clients provided you take appropriate measures during treatment to gain the necessary competence. - Highlight could do a literature review on treating this condition and seek supervision on the case. - Highlight if you are working within an agency setting, you will need to evaluate if the services the clients are seeking fit within the agency’s scope of practice. - Highlight Some agencies specialize in addressing specific issues or problems, and may not want therapists working with clients who are seeking help for other concerns. - Highlight Seek consultation with your supervisor if these concerns arise, especially if there is any ambiguity around whether the issues fit under the agency’s scope of practice. - Highlight there may be occasions where your clients’ needs are best met by working on other goals first before addressing the goals with which they initially present. - Highlight You will need to present a rationale to your clients as to why a particular sequence of treatment will ultimately be in their best interest. - Highlight Client goals are often defined in terms of what problems or issues need to be resolved. In contrast, therapist goals generally reflect what changes clients need to make to resolve their problems. Client goals tell the therapist where they want to go, whereas therapist goals describe how the client will get there. - Highlight Many clients not only bring in expectations about what therapy will accomplish, but also about how therapy will be done. - Highlight helpful to assess what clients expect therapy will be like. - Highlight Whenever a client has had previous therapy, it is often beneficial to explore what the experience was like, as it can strongly shape (both positively and negatively) a client’s expectations regarding therapy. - Highlight What did the client find most useful? What about the process didn’t work for him or her? More specific questions will generate a clearer picture of what occurred and how you might apply it to the current therapy situation. - Highlight the therapist may need to educate clients about the therapy process - Highlight Clients may hold expectations about therapy in a number of different areas. - Highlight You need to assess if their expectations align with what you think is realistic. - Highlight Clients can also have expectations about who will be in therapy. - Highlight It is also important that the therapist and client share similar views on the purpose of therapy. - Highlight If the therapist and client are not on the same page in this regard, then problems are likely to arise. - Highlight The therapist and client will need to discuss what therapy is about and hopefully reach a mutually agreed-upon understanding. - Highlight It is also possible that other client expectations may impede the therapeutic process. - Highlight In some instances, you may decide against continuing therapy because the expectations are too restrictive and would severely limit your ability to be effective. - Highlight Clients come to therapy with varying degrees of motivation. - Highlight The initial interview is a good time to assess and perhaps begin to build motivation for therapy. - Highlight A logical time to assess motivation is when you are defining goals for therapy. Answers to the question “What brings you to therapy?” will differentiate motivated from unmotivated clients. - Highlight some of these clients can become quite committed to therapy as they experience its benefits. - Highlight You should also inquire as to who first suggested therapy or called for the appointment. Generally this person is the most motivated for therapy. A good question to ask your clients is what led them to come - Highlight to therapy now, rather than sooner or later in their lives? - Highlight Where clients are on the Stages of Change Cycle - Highlight may determine their motivation for change. This cycle recognizes that clients spend a great deal of time (precontemplation and contemplation stages) thinking about changing before they decide to take action and change. In addition, the cycle recognizes that maintaining changes, - Highlight can be challenging. Thus, addressing relapse is part of the process leading to permanent change. The therapist must match his or her interventions to where the client is in terms of their stage of change. - Highlight Motivational interviewing - Highlight suggests that the therapist’s job is to help the client resolve his or her ambivalence about change. Instead of using confrontation, the empathic therapist validates the client’s perspective and freedom to decide. - Highlight Pain around unmet needs often drives clients to change. - Highlight it is important that you are clear on what the unmet needs are for your clients, and how much pain or distress they experience around these unmet needs - Highlight You will need to figure out why the client is minimizing the problem, which will guide how you approach the situation. - Highlight it can helpful to explore with clients why others believe there is a problem and the possible negative consequences of not addressing it. - Highlight Sometimes clients will deny that a problem exists out of fear of consequences or injury to their self-image. - Highlight Therefore, building motivation for therapy will need to be done in conjunction with addressing the client’s denial - Highlight If a mandated client refuses to acknowledge that a problem exists, you can suggest that there is at least one problem—he or she is being told to come to unwanted therapy. If your client agrees (which is typically the case), then you can explore what needs to happen so that the client is no longer required to come to therapy. This approach allows you to join with your client, while at the same time working on intermediate goals that address the problem. - Highlight Some clients may have poor motivation because they do not anticipate any benefit from therapy, believing that therapy is useless or the situation is hopeless. - Highlight Building a positive expectation that therapy can be helpful will be vital for these clients - Highlight For clients who lack confidence in their ability to change, you may need to highlight their strengths or help them challenge their negative self-talk. Noting exceptions to the problem might help build confidence and motivation. - Highlight Using the above strategies does not guarantee client motivation. - Highlight In these situations, you need to become comfortable with using the leverage for change provided by the courts. - Highlight A common struggle that beginning therapists may face is when they are more motivated than their clients. - Highlight This dynamic suggests that the therapist needs to step back, review the reasons for therapy, and once again evaluate the clients’ motivation. - Highlight At times, clients might seem motivated “for the wrong reasons.” - Highlight You don’t need to agree with the clients’ motivations. Usually, it is enough that clients, for whatever reason, will face the demanding process of change. - Highlight key issue that the beginning therapist must frequently deal with in the initial session: the issue of credibility. - Highlight In order for clients to have hope or an expectation of change, they must see the therapist and therapy as credible, or they may prematurely terminate therapy. - Highlight assess early on if any issues of credibility need to be addressed. - Highlight do the clients see therapy as an effective way to solve problems? - Highlight do the clients see you, in your role as the therapist, as being competent or credible? - Highlight If you suspect there is a credibility problem, you should attempt to pinpoint where and why credibility is lacking. - Highlight The more precise your understanding of why the client does not see you or the therapy as credible, the more likely your intervention will be “on target” in addressing this issue. - Highlight In cases where clients are resistant to therapy in general, you may be able to reframe the process in a way that builds its credibility. - Highlight you must work to reduce the stigma. You can compare therapy to coaching, in that even the best athletes, - Highlight use coaches. - Highlight When clients question a therapist’s credibility, they usually focus on the lack of professional or life experience. Often you can redefine for the client what type of experience is needed to be helpful. - Highlight If you are concerned about your age and lack of experience, it may also be helpful to dress professionally and present in a professional manner. - Highlight you may need to directly address with your clients how you will compensate for your lack of experience with a particular problem or population. - Highlight you might express your willingness to learn from them about their culture. - Highlight While some clients are open to this approach, others will feel it is not their responsibility to educate the therapist about their culture. - Highlight Especially for these clients, it will be important for you to take the initiative to educate yourself through reading the literature. - Highlight If clients still harbor doubts, a frequently effective strategy is to contract with them for a set number of sessions (perhaps three). This gives you time to demonstrate your competence. - Highlight Nearly all clients are willing to give you this chance, provided the number of sessions is reasonable. - Highlight In these situations, you need to identify a problem that can be quickly resolved to build credibility with your clients. - Highlight It is important that you not become defensive if your credibility is being questioned. If you can deal with your clients’ concerns in a nondefensive and respectful manner, this may actually build your credibility. - Highlight you must be clear in your own mind what you do have to offer, even if you have limited clinical or life experience - Highlight you need to recognize that clients value having someone compassionately and respectfully listen to their story at a difficult time in their lives. - Highlight In simply being present with another human being, you have something important to offer your clients. - Highlight you can frequently offer important insights to your clients because you do not have the kind of emotional involvement in the situation that they do. - Highlight even the inexperienced therapist has access to clinical knowledge that most clients do not possess or could not easily access. - Highlight initial interview is a critical time - Highlight Developing a connection and establishing credibility with your clients is essential for their return for a second session. Defining goals and expectations for therapy, building motivation, and properly handling administrative issues are also crucial. - Highlight You need to remain connected or joined with your clients in order to effectively confront and challenge them at all stages. Likewise, the goals or expectations for therapy may need to be revisited and redefined as therapy proceeds. -
