therapy-theories-and-modalities/narrativ.title: Lecture on Narrative Therapy
therapy-theories-and-modalities/narrativ.description:
Modernism vs. Postmodernism: Postmodernism was a response in many ways to modernism and, hence, they can be considered to be two aspects of the same movement. But there are major differences between modernism and postmodernism. Two central tenets of the Enlightenment (beginning of the 'modern' period) were as follows: The perfectibility of human nature The belief in human progress through the development of human knowledge, especially the sciences. In the 20 th century, scientific findings, like quantum physics, seriously undermined the possibility of a deterministic model of the world. As a guiding principle, reason was still affirmed as was the belief in human progress. The project of modernism was to examine the impediments still holding society back. Individuals ceased to believe that art and literary works bore one unique meaning; rather, postmodernists believed in deriving their own meanings from works of art and literature. Modernism: It was an emancipatory project whose main idea was that traditional values and institutions were oppressive, divisive and inefficient and should, therefore, be replaced by rational values and institutions. Modernism led to progress in many spheres of life by changing the approach of mankind towards culture. Ultimately, modernism attempted to free humanity from its historical baggage through the use of philosophy and science. Postmodernism: Postmodernism was a reaction to modernism and was influenced by disenchantment brought on by the second world war. Postmodernism refers to the state that lacks a central hierarchy and one that is complex, ambiguous, and diverse. Postmodernists are the nihilists. Postmodernists like Heidegger, Derrida, and Lyotard attacked the modernist belief in rationality, objectivity and universalism in favor of relativism (the view that there is no objective truth) as well as identity. Grand narratives like freedom, societal progress, scientific progress were criticized by postmodernists, who instead emphasized that difference, rather than forced unity, should be celebrated. Postmodernism is a backlash against modernity. The collapse of tradition created a frightening situation whereby meaning became difficult to discern amid the horror of societal breakdown. Postmodernism, hence, represented a loss in faith in human reason. Postmodernism provides a bleak prognosis of the human condition and offers no real solutions. Conclusion: - Modernism and postmodernism were both movements that emerged from an analysis of events within the modern period from the perspective of the values of the Enlightenment. Postmodernism: Theory that knowledge of things are not real unless we give them meaning. The sense of self is a social construct. Our identity is created by interactions with other people and our reactions to society. Two threads: Weak (Social Constructionism): Proposes that social constructs are dependent on brute facts (most basic and fundamental facts and do not rely on other facts). Institutional facts are created by social conventions and rely on other facts. Strong (Social): The whole of reality is dependent on social habits. All knowledge is a social construct and there are no brute facts. It would say we created the idea of something and how to explain it. Main criticism: Does not take into consideration the effect of natural phenomenon that goes on in society. Social constructionism only explains reality through the thoughts of humans, not by using fundamental brute facts.
Michael White
David Epston
Gene Combs
Jill Freedman Knowledge is constructed. Therapy is concerned with the ways people interpret their behavior rather than how they behave. Experience is understood in interpretation and meaning making. Experiences can have multiple interpretations. The Narrative Metaphor: Focuses on self-defeating cognitions - the stories people tell themselves about their problems. \Problems affect people. Problems operate on people rather than problems being things people are doing. For clients to maintain their new narratives, they need supportive communities. Hence letter writing, outsider witness, reflecting teams. The truth of experience is not DISCOVERED, it is CREATED. Narrative accounts affect people's perceptions, stories don't just mirror life, they shape it. Instead of trying to solve problems, the focus is on enriching the narratives of people's lives - bringing forth 'thick descriptions' of those aspects of people's narratives that life outside the influence of problems. Alternative stories allow people to live out new identities, new possibilities for relationships, and new future. People find meaning in their lives by experiencing, telling, and circulating stories of un-stories aspects of their lives and relationships. Dominant discourses are socially constructed within our culture. We 'story' and create meaning of life events using available dominant discourses - broad social stories, practices, assumptions, and expectations about how we should live. 'Problems': Experienced when a person's personal life does not fit with these societal discourses and expectations. Process involves separating the person from the problem. Understanding Oppression: Dominant vs. Local Discourses Dominant discourses are culturally generated stories about how life should go. Local discourses occur in our heads, our closer relationships, and marginalized communities. Narrative therapists help clients become aware of how these different discourses are impacting their lives. Avoid judgements about what is 'normal.' Avoid categorizing. Avoid the idea of general principles of what causes problems or what resolves them. The stories people tell themselves. Interpret their experience in unhelpful ways. Patterns of tunnel vision. Problem-saturated stories take hold and encourage people to respond to each other in ways that perpetuate the problem story. Separate the problem-saturated stories to open space for: New and more constructive views of themselves. Look for unique outcomes 'Sparking events' Deconstruction: View the problem as an external entity to start challenging its influence. Unique Outcomes: Resistance to the problem's influence Opens room for counter stories Involves finding new ways to view, interact with, and respond to problems by defining the role of the problems in their lives. Broadly involves the following phases: Meeting Listening Separating persons from problems Enacting preferred narratives Solidifying Process thickens and enriches a person's identity and life accounts. Therapist negotiates the time of each next meeting as therapy progresses, one meeting at a time. At the end of each meeting, the therapists asks whether the conversation has been useful, if it has, they ask how? Then, the therapist asks whether the family would like to meet again, and if so, when? Meetings are typically 60 minutes Length of therapy varies with each family (from a single consultation to years, most somewhere in between) Collaborative Carefully observe, inquire into, and document the family's particular situation in relation to their problem With permission, share knowledge from previous work with families, and ask the family to evaluate the 'fit' and usefulness of that knowledge in relation to their problem Takes notes of what works and what doesn't Decentered, but influential - they have skills in facilitating a conversation Meeting the person apart from the problem Separating people from problems: The problem is the problem Optimism and hope Co-author/co-editor Investigate reporter Problem-saturated stories Unique outcomes and sparkling events Dominant cultural and gender discourses Local and alternative discourses: Attending to client language and meaning Holds a position of curiosity. Cherishes each person/family's unique stories. Invite clients to develop and live out narratives that they prefer for their lives Is decentered, not an expert, but an interested collaborator. They are skilled at asking questions to bring forth the knowledge and experience carried in particular stories of the family. Narrative Therapy Principles: Therapist influential, but decentered. Person separate from problem. All problems have exceptions. Opposite of problem is preferred. Preferred story woven into identity. Impact of relationships explored. Deconstruct societal norms. Personal decision making supported. Instead of having a problem or being a problem, clients are struggling against their problems. The problem is the problem. Aren't interested in problem-maintaining sequences (strategic), structural issues (structural), or solutions (solution-focused), they are interested in the problem's impact on the family.
Social Constructionism: There is no absolute truth, instead shift toward deconstructing (reexamining) established truths that oppress people's lives. People have good intentions (they do not need or want problems). People are profoundly influenced by the discourses around them. People are not their problems. People can develop alternative empowering stories once separated from their problems and the cultural myths they have internalized. Therapist is interested in families' own evaluations of what is problematic and what is preferred. Clients name how the problem is affecting their lives and relationships. Therapist invites people to bring their 'best selves' into consideration of the problems that diminish their relationship and an exploration of how they might choose ways of living that diminish the effect of the problems on their relationship. Reject categorizing people. In the spirit of collaboration, the therapist situates themselves WITH clients. They disclose the beliefs that inform their therapy so that clients can know what they're getting into. Clients are encouraged to educate the therapist on their cultural predicaments and to correct the therapist when they make assumptions that don't fit for the client's experience. Problems are likely to persist as long as unhelpful stories remain fixed and obscure other more helpful versions of events. Cautious about applying terminology (diagnosis). Want to hear the family's stories of how the problems they name affect their lives and relationships. When one of these problems appears to have invaded a relationship, it is the therapist's responsibility to ask questions that invite family members to consider the effects of that problem on their relationship, and to consider the stand they want to take in relation to it. Problems are things that are separate from the families they afflict. Therapists look for problematic discourses and offer families the opportunity to describe and evaluate the effects of those discourses on their relationships and lives. Problem-saturated stories encourage people to respond to each other in ways that perpetuate the problem story Problems may be regarded as alien invaders Separate from problem-saturated stories (and destructive cultural assumptions) Open space for new and more constructive views of themselves. Separate individuals from problems and unite the family to fight a common enemy Search for unique outcomes (sparkling events, exceptions) - times when they resisted the problem or behaved in ways that contradicted the problem story. Help clients deconstruct unproductive stories in order to reconstruct new and more productive ones.
Deconstruction involves questioning assumptions
Reconstruction involves creating new and more optimistic accounts of experience Effects Questions: Elicit effects of the problem "How does the problem affect you? Your ideas about yourself? Your relationship?" "Clients can begin to notice areas of their lives where the problem has been less powerful." Identifying unique outcomes creates room for counterplots Telling and retelling, witnessing, and living out of multistoried lives. Once people notice how their stories are problem saturated and try to change their narratives, what they do and perceive will change as well. Facilitate this process by asking questions to highlight un-storied events and to encourage meaning making around those events, then tie the meaning to memorable actions and contexts. Therapist negotiates the time of each next meeting as therapy progresses, one meeting at a time At the end of each meeting, the therapist asks whether the conversation has been useful, if it has, they ask how? Then, the therapist asks whether the family would like to meet again, and if so, when? Meetings are typically 60 minutes Length of therapy varies with each family (from a single consultation to years, most somewhere in between) CAUTION: Often therapy invites people to re-immerse themselves in their most problematic stories INSTEAD: narrative therapy invite families to explore, describe, and experience new directions in life that are already unfolding - new positions, new stories Counterstory Asking permission is central to the model At the start of the first meeting, the therapist ask if it would be okay to get to know the family in ways that have nothing to do with the problem before they describe what brought them to therapy. Later meetings often start by the therapist reading their notes from the previous session aloud and asking question, such as: Can you tell me about new developments that relate to what we were talking about last time Other times the therapist begins by wondering whether there have been important thoughts or events that connect to possibilities identified in the previous conversations Therapists use letters, documents, and videos to document and circulate alternative stories. For example, after a therapy session a therapist may write a letter posing questions that invite the family to develop an alternative story even further than they did in the session Or sending a document noting the stands the family has taken in regard to a problem Reading a document between sessions, and the conversations that can follow a reading, keeping a story alive and growing Collaborative Carefully observe, inquire into, and document the family's particular situation in relation to their problem. With permission, share knowledge from previous work with families, and ask the family to evaluate the 'fit' and usefulness of that knowledge in relation to their problem. Takes note of what works and what doesn't Decentered, but influential - they have skills in facilitating a conversation Therapy is a relationship - a conversation Ask questions to expose gaps in problematic stories Open space for describing alternatives Invite families to add, subtract, or describe differently Encourage families to ask questions about the therapist's questions and comments The therapist wants the family to make meaning of their own experience, but the therapist's questions inevitably shape the inquiry. Families are in a better position to interpret, making meaning of, and evaluate their own experiences than outsiders are, even trained outsiders Therapists have more questions than answers It sounds as though problem is part of your life now. How long have you been noticing this problem? What effect does the problem have on your life? How does the problem impact your relationships? Does problem have an impact on your relationship with other family members? What do you think about the effects the problem is having on your life? Are you accepting what problem is doing? Are these effects acceptable to you or not? Why is this? Why are you taking this position on what problem is doing? How would you prefer things to be? People's lives are multi-storied, each new telling of a story generates new possibilities for making meaning and taking action. The therapist invites family members to: Evaluate their current situation Name the problems involved Evaluate their relationship to those problems Take a stand in regard to them Tell more satisfying stories of their lives Evaluate the usefulness of the alternative stories In telling and living out the newly developed strands of alternative stories, clients evaluate aspects of their lives. Private hopes and fears Family interactions Contributions of culture of origin Traditions, legacies Questioning: Is that the problem speaking? Whose values are guiding you in saying that? By exposing discouses that support problems, families can separate from the ways of being that are supported by those discourses, and identify and recognize preferred perceptions, attitudes, and actions. What name would you give the problem? What is it like to experience the problem? What effect does the problem have on your life? What effect does the problem have on your relationship with each other? What talks have you have about the problem in your family? What impacts has that had? What effects does the problem have on your other relationships? How does the problem alter your relationship with yourself? Is this what you want for your life? Why or why not? Are we talking about what you want to be talking about? Is this conversation useful? How is it useful? Externalizing conversations Relatice influence questions Who's in charge, the person or the problem? Identifying unique outcomes Reading between the lines of the problem story Can you remember a time... Reauthoring What does it say about you... Illuminating or creating the counter-story Reinforcing the new story Finding audiences, supportive witnesses, allies Letter writing Deconstructing destructive cultural assumptions Listen to stories as stories. Be attentive and responsive to their intended meaning in telling the story. Ask about non-problematic aspects of the life of family members and of their relationship. Make sure the problem does not trick us into mistaking 'them' for 'the problem.' Unless families insist on moving quickly into talking about problems, spend a while listening to stories about their preferences. At some point, families spontaneously start to tell problem saturated stories. Try to put yourself in their shoes. Do not assume you understand the meaning their experience holds for them Listen and ask Listen with focused attention, patience, and curiosity while building a relationship of mutual respect and trust. Listen 'deconstructively' to family stories - the listening is guided by the belief that those stories have many possible meanings. Ask families to tell their stories, look for opportunities to reflect our sense of what they said, they are saying, and to ask whether the meaning we are making fits with their intended meaning. We wonder aloud whether they are useful or desirable? And, what difference it makes to think of it 'that way'? Cultivate an awareness of the dominant (and dominating) stories in our society/ Develop ways of collaboratively examining the effects of those stories when we sense them at work win the lives and relationships of the families with whom we consult. There are 'taken-for-granted' realities at play. Deconstructive questions aim to examine problems in detail and expose discourses that suppose them, as well as those that might undermine those discourses. The person/family is not the problem; the problem is the problem. Externalizing - problems are seen as separate from people. As we listen to people's stories, we listen for the ways they refer to their problems in their lives. If we hear names like 'fear' or 'blowing up,' we orient to those things as entities or processes that are external to families. If we are not hearing the name, we might ask the family to name them. What would you call that something? What 'feeds' the problem? What 'starves' the problem? In what settings might the problem be useful? Who advocates for the problem? What groups of people would be opposed to the problem and its intentions? What are the effects of the problem on members of the family? On their lives and relationships? Naming a problem can open a way for examining it and thinking differently about it. As we ask people to evaluate their relationship to problems, they often tell us what they would prefer to have in their lives in place of the problem. What are the family's preferred directions? 'Standing against' the problem. Have you ever been able to escape the problem even for a few minutes? Is the problem always with you? Listen for purposes, values, hopes, and commitments that are absent but implicit in family's narratives. Double listening. If a person experiences despair, they must have hopes, dreams, or visions of the future that are not being fulfilled. If a person experiences injustive, they must have a conception of a just world. When we hear problematic stories, we listen for these sorts of implications. Stories need listeners as well as tellers. Attentive witnesses. The therapist serves as a witness, but including other witnesses, especially those involved in people's lives, can be very helpful. What was it like to hear what so-and-so was saying? What thoughts were you having as so-and-so was talking? It is useful to ask questions that, rather than leaving the field for response wide open, more specifically invite people to respond to unique outcomes and preferred directions. Were you surprised when so-and-so described you as taking the time to let others know you care? What did it mean to you to hear so-and-so say how important the relationship is to them? Creating a setting where people can tell their preferred stories to a group of outsiders, who then amplify and accredit the stories that they witness. What stood out for them? What images it brought forward? How it resonated with their own experiences? Where they were transported by the interview? Situate their reflections in their own experience. Comment on the difference that being part of the conversation makes on their own lives. We are interested in documenting and circulating the new stories that emerge in therapy to thicken them and keep them alive. We take notes in therapy to document new stories as they develop. We often refer back to these notes and read them aloud. We may create videos or documents about what they have learned, with their permission, that can be viewed or read by others facing similar problems. We sometimes write letters between therapy sessions. In these letters, we ask questions that we did not ask in the therapy session. Our intention in letter writing is to thicken and extend the knowledge that has begun to emerge in session. We might invite the family to share these documents with other people in their lives. Opening space questions (unique outcomes) Has there been a time when arguing could have taken control of your relationship but didn't? Preference questions (preferred experiences) Was this way of handling things better or worse? And how? Story development questions How is this different from when arguing is in control? Meaning questions What does it say about you that you were able to...? Questions that extend the story into the future What do you predict...? Aims to separate the individual from the issue and externalize problems instead of internalizing them. Reality is socially constructed. Reality is influenced by and communicated through language. Having a narrative can help us organize and maintain our reality. There is no 'objective reality' or absolute truth. Telling One's Story: A technique that involves re-telling your own story to find new meaning in old experiences. Externalization Technique: Externalizing helps you separate you from your problems, making it easier to change something you don't like about yourself. Deconstruction Technique: This technique involves breaking problems down into smaller, more specific issues that are easier to understand and address. Unique Outcomes Technique: To help you see from a new, more positive perspective, broaden your view to see more of your own storylines, and focus on one that doesn't include your most pervasive problems. Some families prefer a different kind of therapy than narrative, some are seeking instruction and expert advice. Regularly ask families how the therapy is going for them, and be open and willing to refer families if they are seeking a different kind of relationship. Most families coming to therapy are concerned less with how the therapy is structured than with whether their family relationships improve Emphasis on 'practice-based evidence' over evidence-based practice More qualitative research rather than quantitative studies Little empirical support currently exists Randomized controlled trials of narrative therapy do not yet exist.

therapy-theories-and-modalities/other-th.title: Family Systems Theory
therapy-theories-and-modalities/other-th.description:
Murray Bowen
"Based on the assumptions that the human is a product of evolution and that human behavior is significantly regulated by the same natural processes that regulate the behavior of all other living things. A corollary assumption is that clinical disorders are a product of that part of man he has in common with the lower animals." (@kerrFamilyEvaluation1988)

therapy-theories-and-modalities/other-th.title: General Systems Theory
therapy-theories-and-modalities/other-th.description: A biological model of living systems as whole entities that maintain themselves through continuous input and output from the environment; developed by Ludwig con Bertalanffy. Developed by Ludwig von Bertalanffy A system is 'any entity maintained by the mutual interaction of its parts.' A system can be composed of smaller subsystems. Every system is a subsystem of larger systems. Open vs. Closed Systems Unlike machines, families change when necessary to adapt to new circumstances. Systems: Individual and Nuclear Family (Nuclear Family, Family One Lives Within) Extended Family (Grandparents, Relatives, Significant Others) Social Level (School, Work, Friends, Neighbors, Faith) Multi-Cultural Level (Socioeconomic, Cultural, Ethnic, Racial, Geographical, Religious Context) Implications for MFTs: What shows up as one individual's behavior may be a product of the relationship. MFTs use concepts to describe how people in a relationship contribute to what goes on between them (e.g., pursuer/distancer; overfunctioning/underfunctioning) Families tend to resist change, which explains why so many clients remain stuck despite heroic efforts to improve.

therapy-theories-and-modalities/other-th.title: Multiple Impact Therapy (1967)
therapy-theories-and-modalities/other-th.description:
An intensive, crisis-oriented form of family therapy developed by Robert MacGregor in which family members are treated in various subgroups by a team of therapists.
Robert MacGregor
He developed Multiple Impact Therapy (1967) at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston. His clinic served a population that was scattered widely over southeastern Texas, and clients had to travel hundreds of miles. He wanted to have a maximum impact in a short amount of time. He worked with families for two days.

therapy-theories-and-modalities/solution.title: Lecture on Solution-Focused Therapy
therapy-theories-and-modalities/solution.description:
“Media/Clinic Media/HDFS 8874_ SFT Handout.pdf” could not be found. Solution Focused Brief Therapy Association - Home
What is Solution-Focused Therapy · Solution-Focused Therapy Institute
Steve de Shazer: 1979: Started the Brief Family Therapy Center (BFTC)
Worked in University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Palo Alto (1952); influenced by MRI Focuses on solutions that work rather than solutions that do not work as in the MRI model.
Insoo Kim Berg: BFTC Applied the model to alcoholism, marital therapy, and family-based services to the poor. Derived from MRI Focus on cognitions rather than behavior Focus on the presenting the problem Find the simplest solution Focus on exceptions Exceptions to client's problem are the solution Assumed people are capable of behaving effectively; blocked by negative mindset People already have the solution(s) to their problems. People constrained by narrow view of their problems. Rigid patterns of false solutions Future-oriented Look to future where problems can be solved. Changing the way people talk about their problems. The language of problems tends to be different from the language of solutions. Problem talk: Negative Focuses on the past Implies permanence of problems Solution talk: Hopeful Future oriented Avoid judgements about 'what is normal' Clients as experts in their situation Interest in language How people describe themselves and problems Focus on complaints presented Should not impose values by suggesting clients address other un-presented problems. Solutions to problems are unrelated to the development of the problem. Tracking the development of the problem should be avoided. Problem-focused thinking prevents effective solutions from being recognized. Set clear goals and build on exceptions to problems. Good therapy is more than implementing specific techniques, it also involves therapeutic alliance. The goal of solution-focused therapy is to resolve the presenting problem as expeditiously as possible. The goal is not about how families should be structured, but only what they want different in their lives. The model emphasizes the importance of assisting clients in creating well-defined goals, framed in positive terms and modest enough to be achievable. Resolve presenting complaint by helping clients do or think differently. Trust clients to reach their own goals. Help clients identify the problem-solving skills they have lost sight of. Help clients locate their resources. Time limited Sessions are made one at a time One may be enough Typical course includes 3-5 sessions Clients can return as-needed Often a week to a few weeks apart Once you know more of what works, do more of it Consultant Don't get bogged down in 'problem talk' Direct clients away from the problem-saturated narrative Therapists attempts to create a context for the family to develop more useful ways of responding Focus on the 'here and now' The future provides a blank canvas on which the family can paint a picture of their wishes and hopes Assumes a position of 'not knowing' Very little intake information Avoid assessing how problems develop Concentrate on assessing future goals Therapy should only include people concerned about the problem Hear the client's constructions of their problems without preconceptions What do you think the problem is now? How will you know when the problem is solved? How will you know when you don't have to come here anymore? What will the signs be? What will have to be different for that to happen in terms of your behavior, thoughts, and feelings? What will you notice that is different about others involved in the situation? What is your wildest fantasy about what you want to happen? What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that afterward you will look back and be able to say it was a good idea? What needs to happen so that this will not have been a waste of your time? Often in our experience, we have found that in between scheduling an appointment and coming in, something happens that contributes to making a problem better. Has anything happened to improve the problems that brought you here today? Once a description of the goal has been developed, the therapist asks the clients to assess their current level of progress toward that goal by imagining a scale of 1-10. Where 1 represented the problem at its worst, and 10 is the point at which the problem is gone or the clients are coping so well that its no longer problematic Solution-focused therapists help clients identify their preferred solution by: Talking about the problem, exceptions, and desired outcomes. Working with clients to take small active steps in this general direction each week. This can take 1-10 sessions or it may take years depending on the complexity of the case. How do we know when to stop meeting like this? Goals should be: Small Salient to clients Concrete, behavioral, measurable Achievable Involve hard work Start of something Involve new behaviors What will be present? What will be happening? Activates problem-solving mindset by giving people a vision of their goal. Helps clients to look beyond the problem to see what they really want Might not be the elimination of the problem but to be able to do things that the problem has been obstructing "Suppose one night there is a miracle and while you are sleeping the problem that brought you into therapy is solved." How would you know? What would be different? What will you notice the next morning that will tell you there has been a miracle? What will your family member notice? Directs clients' attention to times when they did not have the problem and expand on exceptions. Helping families see that their problems have exceptions - times when they don't occur. Exceptions are solutions that families already have in their repertoire. Finding exceptions in the recent past is most useful because clients can remember them in greater detail; also since these exceptions just happened, it is more plausible they could happen again. When in the recent past might the problem have happened but didn't (or was less intense or more manageable)? What's different about those times when the problem doesn't happen? How have you let your partner know when they do something that makes a positive difference to you? Punctuate with enthusiasm and support. Work to keep solution talk in the forefront. Listen carefully for an exception by getting more details about it and congragulating the family on it. Connect the exception to the family's goals by asking how the goal would be reached if this exception were to occur more often. "How did you manage that?" "What keeps you going under such difficult circumstances?" "How come things aren't worse?" "What have you done to keep them from getting worse?" Help therapist and clients talk about vague topics (e.g., depression) On a scale from 1 to 10, how sad do you feel? Help clients to set goals in a clear/manageable manner. What do you think you need to do to achieve a 3? To be effective, compliments should point toward what to do more, not what to eliminate. Compliments can be used to highlight successful strategies and keep clients focused on those that work. Formula first-session task Do more of what works Do soemthing different Go slow Do the opposite The prediction task Devote to finding, amplifying, and measuring progress. Inquire about progress, seeking detailed descriptions of any movement toward the family's goal and the clients' role in attaining it. What's better? What happened that you liked? Tell me more. Walk me through how the two of you did that. How did you keep things from getting worse? What's your idea about what might be helpful? How can we know when to stop meeting like this? What needs to be different in your life as a result of coming here for you to say that meeting with me was worthwhile? Toxic positivity Therapist doesn't get to know client's past, which make it harder to understand and empathize with client The brief, goal-oriented focus does not work with every kind of person or problem It is easier to focus on the positive and solutions than to do the deep, difficult work of talking about trauma and the past

therapy-theories-and-modalities/strategi.title: Don Jackson
therapy-theories-and-modalities/strategi.description:
Family Homeostasis
Don Jackson developed the concept of Family Homeostasis.
He and Jay Haley were influential in developing family treatment. They explored marital family therapy within the framework of communication analysis.
Family therapy was started by John Elderkin Bell (1951), Don Jackson, Nathan Ackerman, and Murray Bowen.
Family Rules Rules can describe regularity rather than regulation. Families only use a fraction of the full range of behaviors available to them. Therapy allows the family to access a wider range of behaviors. Jackson's strategies are based on the premise that psychiatric problems resulted from the way people behave with each other. To discern functional interactions from dysfunctional ones is to understand problems in context. Even positive change can be a threat to the defensive order of things. Some therapists believed symptoms serve a purpose by some families needing a sick member, which leads to parents victimizing scapegoated children.

therapy-theories-and-modalities/strategi.title: Jay Haley
therapy-theories-and-modalities/strategi.description:
Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019: "Jay Haley was always something of a maverick. He entered the field without clinical credentials and established his reputation as a gadfly and critic. His initial impact came from his writings, in which he infused sarcasm with incisive analysis. "
Strategies of Psychotherapy, Jay Haley Covert messages are used in the struggle for control that characterizes many relationships Symptoms represent an incongruence between levels of communication Since symptomatic behavior wasn’t reasonable, Haley didn’t try to reason with patients to help them Defined therapy as a directive form of treatment and acknowledged his debt to Milton Erickson, with whom he studied hypnosis. In what he called brief therapy, Haley zeroed in on the context and possible function of a patient’s symptoms. therapist is directing patients to do precisely what they would do anyway and thus subtly gaining the upper hand The decisive techniques in brief therapy were directives it isn’t enough to explain problems to patients; what counts is getting them to do something about them. paradox here is that you can’t accidentally make a mistake if you are doing so deliberately The cybernetic principle here: People will do anything to get out of housework

therapy-theories-and-modalities/strategi.title: Lecture on Strategic Family Therapy
therapy-theories-and-modalities/strategi.description:
Strategic grew out of Gregory Bateson's project on schizophrenia at the Mental Research Institute.
The initial emphasis was on observation and research on families, but due to the influence of University Resources/HDFS Classes/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Figures/Milton Erickson's work, intervention strategies were also formulated. Believed in using the resources of his clients and designing a 'strategy for each specific problem.' He did not care about perspective (insight) as long as their actions produced beneficial results. Conducted therapy by paying extreme attention to details of symptoms his clients presented. IN therapy: Accepted and emphasized positive Used indirect and ambiguously worded directives. Directed routine behaviors so that the resistance is shown through change and not through normal and continuous actions. The MRI Model, Milan Model, and Haley and Madanes all overlap. The MRI Pioneers:
Don Jackson
Gregory Bateson, as a consultant
Virginia Satir (1988)
John Weakland
Jay Haley
Paul Watzlawick
Richard Fisch
Jules Riskin The hallmarks of strategic therapy are: Using a set of novel strategies to solve family problems. Generating change rather than generating insight. Circumventing resistance rather than dealing directly with it. People are always communicating. All behavior is communicative One cannot not communicate. All messages have report and command functions. Report = CONTENT = Information = WHAT IS SAID Command = PROCESS = Underlying Relationship = HOW IT IS SAID Families often perpetuate problems by their own actions. Directives tailored to the needs of a particular family can sometimes bring about sudden and decisive change. The exchange of multilayered messages between family members define their relationships. Interrupting vicious cycles that occur when attempts to solve problems only make them worse. Focuses on identifying and interrupting 'ironic processes' which occur when repeated attempts to solve a problem keep the problem going or make it worse. The aim of therapy is simply to resolve the presenting complaint as quickly and efficiently as possible, so clients can get on with life. BSCT makes no attempt to specify what constitutes a functional or dysfunctional family relationship. The therapist attends to what clients do, as well as, how they view the problem, themselves, and each other. Often see family members individually in the context of family therapy, even when the focus of the intervention is a relational complaint. If no one registers a complaint, there is no problem. Patterns (e.g., quiet detachment, volatile engagement) may be dysfunctional for some families and adaptive for others. What matters is the extent to which interaction patterns based on attempted solutions keep a complaint going or make it worse. The problems clients being to therapy persist only if they are maintained by ongoing current behavior of the family. How a problem persists is much more relevant to therapy than how the problem originated. The behavior of one member of the family is stimulated and shaped by the response of the others. Well-intentioned yet ironic solutions break the vicious cycle (positive feedback loops) that maintain an impasse. The rules or regularities of family interaction that operate to preserve family stability. The conservation aspect of family systems (similar to cybernetic concept of negative feedback). When a specific behavior within a system changes. When the rules of a system change. Rules are typically unspoken, and govern most behavior. When rules promote rigid attempted solutions, it isn't just the behavior, but the rule needs to change.
When a specific behavior within a system changes = First-Order Change
When the rules of the system change = Second-Order Change Families are stuck in a spiraling positive feedback loop. They make common sense but ineffective attempts to change responses. For example: When a younger sibling arrives, the older sibling, feeling unloved, starts screaming for attention. The parent punishes him which reinforces his feelings of being unloved, and he continues to throw tantrums. The job is simply to get the family moving again. Help families define clear and reasonable goals so that everyone knows when treatment has been successful. Alter specific patterns of communication that maintain problems. MRI: The way to resolve problems is to reverse the misguided solutions that have been maintaining them. Haley: Changes in behavior alter perceptions (rather than the other way around). Milan: Get families to see things differently (through reframing or positive connotation), rather than in getting family members to behave differently. MRI Group: Carefully defining the presenting problem and figuring out why it is perpetuated. Non-historic and symptom focused. Haley and Madanes: Examine behavioral sequences around the problem. Examine structural anomalies (weak parental hierarchies, cross-generational coalitions) Milan Group: Preliminary hypothesis tested using circular questioning (systemic explanations). Find the most motivated person in the system. Gain clear understanding of problem (symptom). "What will be the first signs that things are getting better?" Inquire about attempted solutions. Observe and interrupt problem-maintaining sequences. Use therapeutic paradox. Family encourages depressed member to be sad so he feels less guilt for not being happy. The solution is to deny that a problem exists; action is necessary but not taken. The solution is an effort to solve something that isn't really a problem; action is taken when it should not be. The solution is an effort to solve a problem within a framework that makes solution impossible; action is taken but at the wrong level. Haley joins and interviews the entire family. Social Stage -> Problem Stage -> Interaction Stage -> Goal-Setting Stage -> Task-Oriented Stage Each family member should speak and introduce themselves. Therapist should ensure problems are not discussed until everyone can speak. Therapist should examine family seating arrangements to assess organization. Keep conclusions tentative. Shift to the therapy stage. Inquire why the family is there and what the problem is. Be general and ambiguous so the family can expand. Respect the family hierarchy to gain cooperation. Treat those who have power and influence in the family with respect. Therapist should not share observations with the family. Therapist should think of the problems in terms of more than one person. It is critical family members interact with one another rather than with the therapist. Therapist should redirect family members toward each other. Assess family organization through interactions. Families need to define desired changes. Therapist can act as wise advisor and assist the family in setting goals. Use of directives (interventions aimed at targeting and changing specific behaviors). Pre-Session, Session, Intersession, Intervention, Post-Session Discussion Positive connotation (reframing without blaming) Circular questioning Team approach (Reflecting team, greek chorus) Neutrality Responsible for guidance of treatment. We are going to focus on what the problem is. Be aware of timing and pacing. Meet client where they are. Take the time (to form treatment plans) Respond to subtle pressure from clients. Avoid attempting interventions prematurely. Gather enough data about where the client is at before making attempts at intervention. Use of Qualifying Language: "I have a suggestion to make, but I am not sure how much it will accomplish. It will depend on your ability to use your imagination..." Getting client to be specific. Taking one-downmanship. The inherent power difference in therapy Determining the format of meeting. Individual vs. Conjoint In what situation will individual session be beneficial? 'Window Shopper' Client: Re-negotiate contract Working with the complainant Get them down to business Restrictive Client: Ask permission to redirect Setting specific boundary Asking a couple to deliberately have an argument during the week in order to help the therapist to understand how they get involved in such no-win encounters and how they are able to get each other to act unreasonably. Discouraging families from trying to change too fast, warning them to go slow and worrying out loud about the possibility of relapse when improvements do occur. Never tell client why we do this. The family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about. Sometimes the therapist prescribes the symptom while secretly hoping the clients will rebel against the directive. As soon as a family member is overwhelmed they are instructed to make a list of all of the things that they might do to sabotage their life. Doing so can take the rebellion out of self-destructive behavior, thus making it less appealing and less impulsive. Offering a different perspective/framework to understand problem behavior. "The use of language to give a new meaning to a situation." (Piercy et al., 1996) Reframes can be offered by asking circular questions: "Who makes you depressed?" "What does dad do when you and mom are fighting?" Changing the frame of reference for understanding behavior leads to change in the rules governing interactions which in turn leads to sustainable change.

therapy-theories-and-modalities/structur.title: Structure
therapy-theories-and-modalities/structur.description:
Recurrent patterns of interaction that define and stabilize the shape of relationships. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Structural Family Therapy Structure is: The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries. The organized pattern in which families interact Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit. Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established. Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system). The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members. The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to one another. As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns. Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family.

therapy-theories-and-modalities/structur.title: Subsystem
therapy-theories-and-modalities/structur.description:
Smaller units in families, determined by generation, sex, or function. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Boundaries
Structural Family Therapy: Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function. Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system. Children are common 'symptom bearers' Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems: Marital/Couple Parental Child/Sibling

therapy-theories-and-modalities/structur.title: Lecture on Structural Family Therapy
therapy-theories-and-modalities/structur.description:
Family is depicted as a system that comprised of Subsystem. A family is functional to the degree that it nurtures its members to negotiate well the demands of the outside world.
Boundaries set limits distinguishing subsystems from one another in varying permeability (from diffuse to rigid). Subsystems separated by a diffuse boundary are enmeshed, whereas subsystems separated by a rigid boundary are disengaged. Major Concepts: Family
Family Structure Structure Predictable sequences or organized patterns in which families interact A set of rules governing behavior patterns Structures typically have some form of hierarchical structure. Reciprocal and complementary functions. Parental involvement with children, over versus under involvement. Structure is expressed through transactional patterns such as:
Hierarchy Determines who (or which subsystem) has power in the system. Any structure in a family is not static, it is developed over time. Hierarchies can be rigid and unfair or weak and ineffective.
Power Alliances
Structure: The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries. The organized pattern in which families interact.
Subsystem: Subsystems are often formed based on the patterns of interactions in a family. Patterns of interaction are largely based on roles and rules. Covert coalitions are often more significant than obvious groupings. Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function. Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system. Children are common 'symptom bearers.' Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems: Marital/Couple Parental Child/Sibling
Boundaries Each subsystems is demarcated by interpersonal boundaries. Boundaries range from rigid to diffuse.
Rigid Boundaries (Disengaged Subsystem)
Rigid boundaries are restrictive and permit little contact with outside subsystems, resulting in Disengagement. Disengaged systems are independent, but isolated. On the plus side, this fosters autonomy. But limits affection and support. Diffuse Boundaries (Enmeshed Subsystem):
Diffuse boundaries are result in Enmeshment. Enmeshed systems offer closeness, but at the expense of independence. Too much closeness can cripple initiative.
Coalition
Patterns
Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit. Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established. Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system)
Triangles
Loyalties Assumptions: The family could have developed a structure different from the dysfunctional one now being displayed. The family processes adaptive resources in its relational repertoire that currently lie dormant. Therapy attempts to activate what is already there, but latent. Offers a framework that brings order and meaning to family transactions. The consistent patterns of family behavior reveal family structure. The emotional boundaries and coalitions that make up a family's structure are abstractions. The concept of family structure enables therapists to intervene in a systematic and organized way. Families seek help for a specific problem. Family therapists look beyond the specifics of those problems to the family's attempts to solve them. Exploring dynamics of interaction. Recognizing the overall organizations of the family regulates those interactions. The model attends to subsystems and boundaries that regulate contact between members. The model emphasizes enactments wherein family members are encouraged to deal directly with one another in session, permitting the therapist to observe and modify their interactions. Structural family therapy provides therapists with a blueprint for how to view patterns of family dynamics. Theoretical Formulations: Basic assumption is that families are organized structurally in certain ways to cope with stress. Organized patterns ensure the survival of the system, all patterns have this purpose. Systems both responds and reacts to internal and external stressors. Problems are symptomatic of the family's inability to be flexible and accommodating of changing needs. All family behavior, even destructive behavior, has the goal of balancing the system to ensure its survival. Family problems do not result from stresses in the system but from the effects of reactions and responses to the stresses. The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members. The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to each other. As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns. Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family. Healthy families not defined by the abundance of problems. But rather by a functioning structure Healthy families can modify their structure to accommodate changing circumstances. Unhealthy families increase rigidity of structures that are no longer functional. Less adaptive families increase rigidity of structures and are no longer functional. Problems arise when there are: Weak hierarchies; conflict avoidance; cross-generational coalitions Inflexible structures Failure to adjust to changing circumstances Failure to reorganize themselves in order to deal with stresses in the home environment. The ultimate goal of therapy is structural changes to the family Alter the family structure so that the family can solve its own problems. General goal: create or strengthen executive subsystem Therapists have two types of assessment tools:
Enactment Spontaneous behavior sequences Enactments occur when a therapist stimulates a family to demonstrate how they handle problems Therapists guide the family how to modify the enactment, creating new behavior sequences. Joining and accommodating (effective therapy requires challenge and confrontation) "The structural therapist needs to relate to family members in a way that validates their experience but does not preclude a challenge to the status quo." Working with interaction (Use of enactments) Mapping structural patterns (Observing enmeshment and disengagement) Focus on the underlying family structure: Highlight and modify interactions Intensity (interrupt rigid and difficult patters) "Challenging to be effective must be predicated on the client's strengths. Contrary to a common misconception, it is not the 'opposite' of joining. Joining and challenging need to be seen as simultaneous qualities in any therapeutic intervention." Help people do things themselves Therapists can invite family members to participate and interact in ways that will Help them function more efficiently Transformation of family structure
Boundary Making Loosen boundaries in disengaged families Strengthen boundaries in enmeshed families Unbalancing
Reframing (adding cognitive constructions) Unbalancing Blocking Stopping usual transactions Exaggerating Encouraging or sustaining interactions Keeping silent When a response is expected, doing the unusual by not giving one, thereby demanding the family to react. Manipulating the intensity Therapist's comfort level with intense emotions
Enactment
Complementarity Summarize the cycle of interaction and clarify the systemic nature of the symptoms, relieve blame from any one person, and direct the way to change.

In 1981, Minuchin started his own center in New York, where he continued to practice and teach until 1996, when he retired and moved to Boston. He retired (again) and moved to Boca Raton, Florida, in 2005, where he conducted professional trainings and taught courses at Nova Southeastern University until his death in 2017.
